name: cas.authn.spnego.ldap.validator.attribute-name
description: Attribute name to use for the compare validator.

name: cas.authn.throttle.jdbc.password
description: The database connection password.

name: cas.authn.pac4j.profile-selection.ldap.idle-time
description: Removes connections from the pool based on how long they have been idle in the available queue. Prunes connections that have been idle for more than the indicated amount.

name: cas.authn.mfa.u2f.redis.connect-timeout
description: Connection timeout.

name: cas.authn.jdbc.query[].physical-naming-strategy-class-name
description: Fully-qualified name of the class that can control the physical naming strategy of hibernate.

name: cas.events.influx-db.database
description: Database name.

name: cas.acceptable-usage-policy.mongo.retry-writes
description: Sets whether writes should be retried if they fail due to a network error.

name: cas.authn.mfa.gauth.core.time-step-size
description: The expiration time of the generated code in seconds.

name: cas.authn.attribute-repository.redis[].cluster.password
description: The cluster connection's password.

name: cas.authn.saml-idp.metadata.redis.scan-count
description: Redis scan count option. When and if specified, SCAN operations would be "counted" or limited by this serting. While SCAN does not provide guarantees about the number of elements returned at every iteration, it is possible to empirically adjust the behavior of SCAN using the COUNT option. Basically with COUNT the user specified the amount of work that should be done at every call in order to retrieve elements from the collection. This is just a hint for the implementation, however generally speaking this is what you could expect most of the times from the implementation.

name: cas.authn.okta.credential-criteria
description:
A number of authentication handlers are allowed to determine whether they can operate on the provided credential and as such lend themselves to be tried and tested during the authentication handler selection phase. The credential criteria may be one of the following options:
  • 1) A regular expression pattern that is tested against the credential identifier.
  • 2) A fully qualified class name of your own design that implements {@code Predicate}.
  • 3) Path to an external Groovy script that implements the same interface.

name: cas.consent.ldap.follow-referrals
description: Set if search referrals should be followed.

name: cas.authn.mfa.u2f.dynamo-db.region
description: AWS region used.

name: cas.authn.passwordless.tokens.mail.html
description: Indicate whether the message body should be evaluated as HTML text.

name: cas.authn.oidc.jwks.mongo.read-preference
description:
Read preference. Accepted values are:
  • {@code PRIMARY}
  • {@code SECONDARY}
  • {@code SECONDARY_PREFERRED}
  • {@code PRIMARY_PREFERRED}
  • {@code NEAREST}

name: cas.authn.mfa.yubikey.dynamo-db.socket-timeout
description: Socket timeout.

name: cas.service-registry.dynamo-db.write-capacity
description: Write capacity.

name: cas.service-registry.stream.hazelcast.config.cluster.discovery.multicast.enabled
description: Enables a multicast configuration using a group address and port. Contains the configuration for the multicast discovery mechanism. With the multicast discovery mechanism Hazelcast allows Hazelcast members to find each other using multicast. So Hazelcast members do not need to know concrete addresses of members, they just multicast to everyone listening. It depends on your environment if multicast is possible or allowed; otherwise you need to have a look at the tcp/ip cluster

name: cas.authn.surrogate.tgt.time-to-kill-in-seconds
description: Timeout in seconds to kill the surrogate session and consider tickets expired.

name: cas.spring.cloud.aws.dynamo-db.endpoint
description: AWS custom endpoint.

name: cas.authn.pac4j.saml[].metadata.service-provider.jdbc.pool.keep-alive-time
description:
This property controls the keepalive interval for a connection in the pool. An in-use connection
will never be tested by the keepalive thread, only when it is idle will it be tested.
Default is zero, which disables this feature.

name: cas.monitor.jdbc.read-only
description: Configures the Connections to be added to the pool as read-only Connections.

name: cas.authn.mfa.trusted.mongo.user-id
description: MongoDb database user for authentication.

name: cas.monitor.mongo
description: Options for monitoring MongoDb resources.

name: cas.authn.jdbc.query[].autocommit
description:
The default auto-commit behavior of connections in the pool.
Determined whether queries such as update/insert should be immediately executed
without waiting for an underlying transaction.

name: cas.monitor.jdbc.pool.keep-alive-time
description: This property controls the keepalive interval for a connection in the pool. An in-use connection will never be tested by the keepalive thread, only when it is idle will it be tested. Default is zero, which disables this feature.

name: cas.saml-sp.net-partner.description
description: Description of this service provider as it's stored in the registry.

name: cas.authn.password-sync.ldap[].trust-store
description:
Path to the keystore used to determine which certificates or
certificate authorities should be trusted.
Used when connecting to an LDAP server via LDAPS or startTLS connection.
If left blank, the default truststore for the Java runtime is used.

name: cas.authn.pac4j.saml[].metadata.service-provider.jdbc.isolate-internal-queries
description:
This property determines whether data source isolates internal pool queries, such as the connection alive test, in their own transaction.

Since these are typically read-only queries, it is rarely necessary to encapsulate them in their own transaction. This property only applies if {@link #autocommit} is disabled.

name: cas.authn.mfa.simple.bucket4j.bandwidth
description: Describe the available bandwidth and the overall limitations. Multiple bandwidths allow for different policies per unit of measure. (i.e. allows 1000 tokens per 1 minute, but not often then 50 tokens per 1 second).

name: cas.authn.authentication-attribute-release.only-release
description: List of authentication attributes that should be the only ones released. An empty list indicates all attributes should be released.

name: cas.authn.redis.read-from
description:
Setting that describes how Lettuce routes read operations to replica nodes. Note that modes referencing MASTER/SLAVE are deprecated (but still supported) in the Lettuce redis client dependency so migrate config to UPSTREAM/REPLICA. Available values are as follows:
  • {@code UPSTREAM}: Read from the current upstream node.
  • {@code UPSTREAMPREFERRED}: Read from the upstream node, but if it is unavailable, read from replica nodes.
  • {@code MASTER}: Read from the current upstream node.
  • {@code MASTERPREFERRED}: Read from the upstream node, but if it is unavailable, read from replica nodes.
  • {@code SLAVE}: Read from replica nodes.
  • {@code SLAVEPREFERRED}: Read from the replica nodes, but if none is unavailable, read from the upstream node.
  • {@code REPLICA}: Read from replica nodes.
  • {@code REPLICAPREFERRED}: Read from the replica nodes, but if none is unavailable, read from the upstream node.
  • {@code ANY}: Read from any node of the cluster.
  • {@code ANYREPLICA}: Read from any replica node of the cluster.
  • {@code NEAREST}: Read from the nearest node.

name: cas.authn.pac4j.profile-selection.ldap.page-size
description: Request that the server return results in batches of a specific size. See RFC 2696. This control is often used to work around server result size limits. A negative/zero value disables paged requests.

name: cas.authn.accept.principal-transformation.blocking-pattern
description: A regular expression that will be used against the username to match for blocking/forbidden values. If a match is found, an exception will be thrown and principal transformation will fail.

name: cas.acceptable-usage-policy.ldap[].use-start-tls
description: Whether TLS should be used and enabled when establishing the connection.

name: cas.interrupt.groovy.location
description:
The location of the resource. Resources can be URLs, or files found either on the classpath or outside somewhere in the file system.

In the event the configured resource is a Groovy script, specially if the script set to reload on changes, you may need to adjust the total number of {@code inotify} instances. On Linux, you may need to add the following line to {@code /etc/sysctl.conf}: {@code fs.inotify.max_user_instances = 256}.

You can check the current value via {@code cat /proc/sys/fs/inotify/max_user_instances}.

name: cas.authn.jdbc.query[].principal-attribute-list
description: List of column names to fetch as user attributes.

name: cas.authn.mfa.authy.bypass.principal-attribute-name
description: Skip multifactor authentication based on designated principal attribute names.

name: cas.authn.accept.name
description: Name of the authentication handler.

name: cas.service-registry.jpa.dialect
description: The database dialect is a configuration setting for platform independent software (JPA, Hibernate, etc) which allows such software to translate its generic SQL statements into vendor specific DDL, DML.

name: cas.authn.saml-idp.metadata.amazon-s3.bucket-name
description: S3 bucket that contains metadata files.

name: cas.authn.attribute-repository.redis[].order
description:
The order of this attribute repository in the chain of repositories.
Can be used to explicitly position this source in chain and affects
merging strategies.

name: cas.consent.core.crypto.signing.key
description: The signing key is a JWT whose length is defined by the signing key size setting.

name: cas.webflow.session.server.hazelcast.cluster.discovery.gcp.zones
description: A list of zones where the plugin looks for instances; if not set, all zones of the current region are used.

name: cas.saml-sp.workday.description
description: Description of this service provider as it's stored in the registry.

name: cas.authn.syncope.provisioning.realm
description: Syncope realm used for principal provisioning. Realms define a hierarchical security domain tree, primarily meant for containing users. The root realm contains everything, and other realms can be seen as containers that split up the total number of entities into smaller pools.

name: cas.interrupt.rest.basic-auth-password
description: If REST endpoint is protected via basic authentication, specify the password for authentication.

name: cas.saml-sp.zendesk.sign-assertions
description: Indicate whether assertions should be signed.

name: cas.authn.mfa.u2f.rest.headers
description: Headers, defined as a Map, to include in the request when making the REST call. Will overwrite any header that CAS is pre-defined to send and include in the request. Key in the map should be the header name and the value in the map should be the header value.

name: cas.service-registry.redis.cluster.nodes[].type
description:
Indicate the type/role of this node.
Accepted values are: {@code MASTER, REPLICA}.

name: cas.saml-sp.black-baud.attributes
description: Set up the attribute release policy for this service. Allow attributes that are to be released to this SP. Attributes should be separated by commas and can be virtually mapped and renamed.

name: cas.authn.surrogate.simple.search-entry-handlers[].dn-attribute.add-if-exists
description: The Add if exists.

name: cas.authn.mfa.web-authn.ldap.follow-referrals
description: Set if search referrals should be followed.

name: cas.authn.throttle.hazelcast.cluster.network.ssl.mutual-authentication
description:
Mutual authentication configuration. It’s empty by default which means the client side of connection is not authenticated. Available values are:
  • {@code REQUIRED} - server forces usage of a trusted client certificate
  • {@code OPTIONAL} - server asks for a client certificate, but it doesn’t require it

name: cas.audit.jdbc.dialect
description: The database dialect is a configuration setting for platform independent software (JPA, Hibernate, etc) which allows such software to translate its generic SQL statements into vendor specific DDL, DML.

name: cas.authn.ldap[].name
description: Name of the LDAP handler.

name: cas.acceptable-usage-policy.ldap[].sasl-quality-of-protection
description: SASL quality of protected.

name: cas.google-analytics.cookie.path
description: Cookie path. Specifies a path for the cookie to which the client should return the cookie. The cookie is visible to all the pages in the directory you specify, and all the pages in that directory's subdirectories. A cookie's path must include the servlet that set the cookie, for example, /catalog, which makes the cookie visible to all directories on the server under /catalog. Consult RFC 2965 (available on the Internet) for more information on setting path names for cookies.

name: cas.authn.mfa.u2f.crypto.encryption.key
description: The encryption key is a JWT whose length is defined by the encryption key size setting.

name: cas.authn.saml-idp.metadata.jpa.crypto.encryption.key-size
description: The encryption key size.

name: cas.authn.jaas[].kerberos-kdc-system-property
description:
Typically, the default realm and the KDC for that realm are indicated in the Kerberos {@code krb5.conf} configuration file. However, if you like, you can instead specify the realm value by setting this following system property value.

If you set the realm property, you SHOULD also configure the kerberos KDC system property.

Also note that if you set these properties, then no cross-realm authentication is possible unless a {@code krb5.conf} file is also provided from which the additional information required for cross-realm authentication may be obtained.

If you set values for these properties, then they override the default realm and KDC values specified in {@code krb5.conf} (if such a file is found). The {@code krb5.conf} file is still consulted if values for items other than the default realm and KDC are needed. If no {@code krb5.conf} file is found, then the default values used for these items are implementation-specific.

name: cas.authn.mongo.host
description: MongoDb database host for authentication. Multiple host addresses may be defined, separated by comma. If more than one host is defined, it is assumed that each host contains the port as well, if any. Otherwise the configuration may fallback onto the port defined.

name: cas.authn.mfa.gauth.redis.read-from
description:
Setting that describes how Lettuce routes read operations to replica nodes. Note that modes referencing MASTER/SLAVE are deprecated (but still supported) in the Lettuce redis client dependency so migrate config to UPSTREAM/REPLICA. Available values are as follows:
  • {@code UPSTREAM}: Read from the current upstream node.
  • {@code UPSTREAMPREFERRED}: Read from the upstream node, but if it is unavailable, read from replica nodes.
  • {@code MASTER}: Read from the current upstream node.
  • {@code MASTERPREFERRED}: Read from the upstream node, but if it is unavailable, read from replica nodes.
  • {@code SLAVE}: Read from replica nodes.
  • {@code SLAVEPREFERRED}: Read from the replica nodes, but if none is unavailable, read from the upstream node.
  • {@code REPLICA}: Read from replica nodes.
  • {@code REPLICAPREFERRED}: Read from the replica nodes, but if none is unavailable, read from the upstream node.
  • {@code ANY}: Read from any node of the cluster.
  • {@code ANYREPLICA}: Read from any replica node of the cluster.
  • {@code NEAREST}: Read from the nearest node.

name: cas.authn.pac4j.wordpress.auto-redirect-type
description:
Auto-redirect to this client. Available values are as follows:
  • {@code SERVER}: Redirect on the server side, typically making CAS invisible.
  • {@code CLIENT}: Redirect on the client side using browser redirects, etc.
  • {@code NONE}: Do nothing and let the selection take place manually.

name: cas.authn.pac4j.oidc[].keycloak.css-class
description: CSS class that should be assigned to this client.

name: cas.authn.passwordless.tokens.jpa.propagation-behavior-name
description: Defines the propagation behavior for transactions. @see org.springframework.transaction.TransactionDefinition

name: cas.spring.cloud.aws.s3.max-connections
description: Maximum connections setting.

name: cas.authn.passwordless.accounts.ldap.sasl-authorization-id
description: SASL authorization id.

name: cas.monitor.mongo[].password
description: MongoDb database password for authentication.

name: cas.authn.saml-idp.algs.override-blocked-encryption-algorithms
description: The Override black listed encryption algorithms.

name: cas.authn.mfa.trusted.json.location
description:
The location of the resource. Resources can be URLs, or files found either on the classpath or outside somewhere in the file system.

In the event the configured resource is a Groovy script, specially if the script set to reload on changes, you may need to adjust the total number of {@code inotify} instances. On Linux, you may need to add the following line to {@code /etc/sysctl.conf}: {@code fs.inotify.max_user_instances = 256}.

You can check the current value via {@code cat /proc/sys/fs/inotify/max_user_instances}.

name: cas.service-registry.jpa.read-only
description: Configures the Connections to be added to the pool as read-only Connections.

name: cas.authn.jdbc.query[].default-catalog
description: Qualifies unqualified table names with the given catalog in generated SQL.

name: cas.saml-sp.cccco.name-id-attribute
description: Attribute to use when generating nameids for this SP.

name: cas.audit.jdbc.fetch-size
description: Used to specify number of rows to be fetched in a select query.

name: cas.server.tomcat.ajp.allow-trace
description: A boolean value which can be used to enable or disable the TRACE HTTP method. If not specified, this attribute is set to false.

name: cas.authn.passwordless.accounts.ldap.block-wait-time
description: The length of time the pool will block. By default the pool will block indefinitely and there is no guarantee that waiting threads will be serviced in the order in which they made their request. This option should be used with a blocking connection pool when you need to control the exact number of connections that can be created

name: cas.consent.mongo.host
description: MongoDb database host for authentication. Multiple host addresses may be defined, separated by comma. If more than one host is defined, it is assumed that each host contains the port as well, if any. Otherwise the configuration may fallback onto the port defined.

name: cas.webflow.session.server.hazelcast.cluster.discovery.jclouds.regions
description: Defines region for a cloud service (optional). Can be used with comma separated values for multiple values.

name: cas.authn.mfa.web-authn.ldap.sasl-authorization-id
description: SASL authorization id.

name: cas.authn.pac4j.saml[].metadata.service-provider.jdbc.pool.maximum-lifetime
description:
This property controls the maximum lifetime of a connection in the pool. When a connection
reaches this timeout, even if recently used,
it will be retired from the pool. An in-use connection will never be retired, only when it is idle will it be removed.

name: cas.ticket.registry.mongo.password
description: MongoDb database password for authentication.

name: cas.authn.mfa.radius.client.authentication-port
description: The authentication port.

name: cas.authn.mfa.web-authn.ldap.prune-period
description: Removes connections from the pool based on how long they have been idle in the available queue. Run the pruning process at the indicated interval.

name: cas.authn.pac4j.saml[].metadata.service-provider.jdbc.read-only
description: Configures the Connections to be added to the pool as read-only Connections.

name: cas.authn.mfa.simple.token.rest.headers
description: Headers, defined as a Map, to include in the request when making the REST call. Will overwrite any header that CAS is pre-defined to send and include in the request. Key in the map should be the header name and the value in the map should be the header value.

name: cas.events.redis.pool.num-tests-per-eviction-run
description: Sets the maximum number of objects to examine during each run (if any) of the idle object evictor thread. When positive, the number of tests performed for a run will be the minimum of the configured value and the number of idle instances in the pool. When negative, the number of tests performed will be ceil(getNumIdle()/ abs(getNumTestsPerEvictionRun())) which means that when the value is -n roughly one nth of the idle objects will be tested per run.

name: cas.authn.spnego.ldap.trust-manager
description:
Trust Manager options. Trust managers are responsible for managing the trust material that is used when making LDAP trust decisions, and for deciding whether credentials presented by a peer should be accepted. Accepted values are: *
  • {@code DEFAULT}: Enable and force the default JVM trust managers.
  • {@code ANY}: Trust any client or server.

name: cas.saml-sp.docu-sign.name-id-attribute
description: Attribute to use when generating nameids for this SP.

name: cas.ticket.registry.hazelcast.cluster.discovery.jclouds.port
description: Port which the hazelcast instance service uses on the cluster member. Default value is 5701. (optional)

name: cas.authn.adaptive.risk.response.block-attempt
description: If an authentication attempt is deemed risky, block the response and do not allow further attempts.

name: cas.authn.redis.pool.test-on-borrow
description: Returns whether objects borrowed from the pool will be validated before being returned from the borrowObject() method. Validation is performed by the validateObject() method of the factory associated with the pool. If the object fails to validate, it will be removed from the pool and destroyed, and a new attempt will be made to borrow an object from the pool.

name: cas.authn.mfa.trusted.jpa.data-source-name
description: Attempts to do a JNDI data source look up for the data source name specified. Will attempt to locate the data source object as is.

name: cas.authn.pac4j.hi-org-server.scope
description: The requested scope.

name: cas.monitor.endpoints.jdbc.pool.timeout-millis
description: The maximum number of milliseconds that the pool will wait for a connection to be validated as alive.

name: cas.authn.wsfed-idp.sts.signing-keystore-file
description: Keystore path used to sign tokens.

name: cas.authn.cloud-directory.profile-path
description: Profile path.

name: cas.authn.syncope.password-encoder.type
description:
Define the password encoder type to use. Type may be specified as blank or {@code NONE} to disable password encoding. It may also refer to a fully-qualified class name that implements the Spring Security's {@code PasswordEncoder} interface if you wish you define your own encoder.

The following types may be used:

  • {@code NONE}: No password encoding (i.e. plain-text) takes place.
  • {@code DEFAULT}: Use the {@code DefaultPasswordEncoder} of CAS. For message-digest algorithms via {@code character-encoding} and {@code encoding-algorithm}.
  • {@code BCRYPT}: Use the {@code BCryptPasswordEncoder} based on the strength provided and an optional secret.
  • {@code SCRYPT}: Use the {@code SCryptPasswordEncoder}.
  • {@code PBKDF2}: Use the {@code Pbkdf2PasswordEncoder} based on the strength provided and an optional secret.
  • {@code STANDARD}: Use the {@code StandardPasswordEncoder} based on the secret provided.
  • {@code SSHA}: Use the {@code LdapShaPasswordEncoder} supports Ldap SHA and SSHA (salted-SHA). The values are base-64 encoded and have the label {SHA} or {SSHA} prepended to the encoded hash.
  • {@code GLIBC_CRYPT}: Use the {@code GlibcCryptPasswordEncoder} based on the {@code encoding-algorithm}, strength provided and an optional secret.
  • {@code org.example.MyEncoder}: An implementation of {@code PasswordEncoder} of your own choosing.
  • {@code file:///path/to/script.groovy}: Path to a Groovy script charged with handling password encoding operations.

name: cas.authn.jaas[].kerberos-realm-system-property
description:
Typically, the default realm and the KDC for that realm are indicated in the Kerberos {@code krb5.conf} configuration file. However, if you like, you can instead specify the realm value by setting this following system property value.

If you set the realm property, you SHOULD also configure the kerberos KDC system property.

Also note that if you set these properties, then no cross-realm authentication is possible unless a {@code krb5.conf} file is also provided from which the additional information required for cross-realm authentication may be obtained.

If you set values for these properties, then they override the default realm and KDC values specified in {@code krb5.conf} (if such a file is found). The {@code krb5.conf} file is still consulted if values for items other than the default realm and KDC are needed. If no {@code krb5.conf} file is found, then the default values used for these items are implementation-specific.

name: cas.consent.redis.cluster.nodes[].type
description:
Indicate the type/role of this node.
Accepted values are: {@code MASTER, REPLICA}.

name: cas.service-registry.redis.cluster.max-redirects
description: The max number of redirects to follow.

name: cas.events.mongo.write-concern
description: Write concern describes the level of acknowledgement requested from MongoDB for write operations to a standalone mongo db or to replica sets or to sharded clusters. In sharded clusters, mongo db instances will pass the write concern on to the shards.

name: cas.authn.throttle.bucket4j.bandwidth[].capacity
description: Number of tokens/requests that can be used within the time window.

name: cas.authn.pac4j.hi-org-server.css-class
description: CSS class that should be assigned to this client.

name: cas.authn.throttle.hazelcast.cluster.discovery.aws.port
description: Hazelcast port. Typically may be set to {@code 5701}. You can set searching for other ports rather than 5701 if you've members on different ports.

name: cas.authn.redis.password-encoder.iterations
description: When used by {@link PasswordEncoderTypes#PBKDF2}, it indicates the required number of iterations.

name: cas.authn.pac4j.profile-selection.ldap.search-entry-handlers[].merge-attribute.attribute-names
description: The Attribute names.

name: cas.authn.attribute-repository.jdbc[].batch-size
description: A non-zero value enables use of JDBC2 batch updates by Hibernate. e.g. recommended values between 5 and 30.

name: cas.authn.mfa.gauth.jpa.autocommit
description: The default auto-commit behavior of connections in the pool. Determined whether queries such as update/insert should be immediately executed without waiting for an underlying transaction.

name: cas.authn.gua.ldap.search-entry-handlers[].case-change.attribute-value-case-change
description: The Attribute value case change.

name: cas.events.redis.cluster.adaptive-topology-refresh
description: Whether adaptive topology refreshing using all available refresh triggers should be used.

name: cas.saml-sp.black-baud.signature-location
description: Signature location used to verify metadata.

name: cas.authn.mfa.gauth.id
description: The identifier for the multifactor provider. In most cases, this need not be configured explicitly, unless multiple instances of the same provider type are configured in CAS.

name: cas.ticket.registry.memcached.max-total
description: Sets the cap on the number of objects that can be allocated by the pool (checked out to clients, or idle awaiting checkout) at a given time. Use a negative value for no limit.

name: cas.monitor.ldap[].validate-periodically
description: Whether connections should be validated periodically when the pool is idle.

name: cas.authn.mfa.web-authn.name
description: The name of the authentication handler used to verify credentials in MFA. Remember that if you have more than one authentication handler of the same type, the names must be defined uniquely for each authentication scheme. Failing to do so may force CAS to not register authentication handlers with a duplicate name.

name: cas.ticket.registry.memcached.transcoder
description:
Indicate the transcoder type. Available values are as follows:
  • {@code KRYO}: CAS transcoder implementation based on Kryo fast serialization framework suited for efficient serialization of tickets. Provides pooling mechanisms as well as control over object registration and sequences.
  • {@code SERIAL}: Kryp native transcoder that serializes and compresses objects.
  • {@code WHALIN}: Transcoder that provides compatibility with Greg Whalin's memcached client.
  • {@code WHALINV1}: Handles old whalin encoding: data type is in the first byte of the value.

name: cas.authn.surrogate.simple.validator.attribute-name
description: Attribute name to use for the compare validator.

name: cas.authn.attribute-repository.core.default-attributes-to-release
description: CAS provides the ability to release a bundle of principal attributes to all services by default. This bundle is not defined on a per-service basis and is always combined with attributes produced by the specific release policy of the service, such that for instance, you can devise rules to always release {@code givenName} and {@code cn} to every application, and additionally allow other specific principal attributes for only some applications per their attribute release policy.

name: cas.saml-sp.workday.signature-location
description: Signature location used to verify metadata.

name: cas.spring.cloud.aws.secrets-manager.max-connections
description: Maximum connections setting.

name: cas.authn.cassandra.password-encoder.hash-length
description: When used by {@link PasswordEncoderTypes#ARGON2}, it indicates the hash strength/length.

name: cas.authn.surrogate.mail.bcc
description: Email BCC address, if any.

name: cas.authn.mfa.triggers.rest.url
description: The endpoint URL to contact and retrieve attributes.

name: cas.sms-provider.sns.local-address
description: Local address.

name: cas.authn.trusted.person-directory.return-null
description: Return a null principal object if no attributes can be found for the principal.

name: cas.spring.cloud.dynamo-db.billing-mode
description:
Billing mode specifies how you are charged for read and write throughput and how you manage capacity. Available values are as follows:
  • {@code PROVISIONED}: Provisioned mode means that you specify the number of reads and writes per second that you expect your application to use. Provisioned mode is a good option if any of the following are true:
    • You have predictable application traffic.
    • You run applications whose traffic is consistent or ramps gradually.
    • You can forecast capacity requirements to control costs.
    You can use auto scaling to automatically adjust capacity based on the specified utilization rate to ensure application performance while reducing costs.
  • {@code PAY_PER_REQUEST}: Pay-per-request or on-demand billing means that you're charged for only the read/write requests that you use. On-demand mode is a good option if any of the following are true:
    • You create new tables with unknown workloads.
    • You have unpredictable application traffic.
    • You prefer the ease of paying for only what you use.
    Tables using on-demand mode support all DynamoDB features (such as encryption at rest, point-in-time recovery, global tables, and so on) with the exception of auto scaling, which is not applicable with this mode.

Basically with COUNT the user specified the amount of work that should be done at every call in order to retrieve elements from the collection. name: cas.authn.throttle.hazelcast.cluster.core.cp-member-count
description: CP Subsystem is a component of a Hazelcast cluster that builds a strongly consistent layer for a set of distributed data structures. Its data structures are CP with respect to the CAP principle, i.e., they always maintain linearizability and prefer consistency over availability during network partitions. Besides network partitions, CP Subsystem withstands server and client failures. All members of a Hazelcast cluster do not necessarily take part in CP Subsystem. The number of Hazelcast members that take part in CP Subsystem is specified here. CP Subsystem must have at least 3 CP members.

name: cas.service-registry.ldap.search-entry-handlers[].type
description:
The type of search entry handler to choose. Available values are as follows:
  • {@code FOLLOW_SEARCH_REFERRAL}: Provides handling of an ldap referral for search operations.
  • {@code FOLLOW_SEARCH_RESULT_REFERENCE}: Provides handling of an ldap continuation reference for search operations.
  • {@code ACTIVE_DIRECTORY}: Process the entry results fetched from active directory and check for account status controls for disabled/expired accounts, etc.
  • {@code OBJECT_GUID}: Object guid search entry handler. Handles the {@code objectGUID} attribute fetching and conversion.
  • {@code OBJECT_SID}: Object sid search entry handler. Handles the {@code objectSid} attribute fetching and conversion.
  • {@code CASE_CHANGE}: Case change search entry handler. Provides the ability to modify the case of search entry DNs, attribute names, and attribute values.
  • {@code DN_ATTRIBUTE_ENTRY}: DN attribute entry handler. Adds the entry DN as an attribute to the result set. Provides a client side implementation of RFC 5020.
  • {@code MERGE}: Merge search entry handler. Merges the values of one or more attributes into a single attribute.
  • {@code PRIMARY_GROUP}: Primary group search handler. Constructs the primary group SID and then searches for that group and puts it's DN in the {@code memberOf} attribute of the original search entry.
  • {@code RANGE_ENTRY}: Range entry search handler. Rewrites attributes returned from Active Directory to include all values by performing additional searches.
  • {@code RECURSIVE_ENTRY}: Recursive entry search handler. This recursively searches based on a supplied attribute and merges those results into the original entry.
  • {@code MERGE_ENTRIES}: Merge entries handler. Merges the values of one or more attributes in all entries into a single attribute. The merged attribute may or may not already exist on the entry. If it does exist it's existing values will remain intact.

name: cas.consent.jpa.ddl-auto
description:
Hibernate feature to automatically validate and exports DDL to the schema. By default, creates and drops the schema automatically when a session is starts and ends. Setting the value to {@code validate} or {@code none} may be more desirable for production, but any of the following options can be used:
  • {@code validate}: Validate the schema, but make no changes to the database.
  • {@code update}: Update the schema.
  • {@code create}: Create the schema, destroying previous data.
  • {@code create-drop}: Drop the schema at the end of the session.
  • {@code none}: Do nothing.

Note that during a version migration where any schema has changed {@code create-drop} will result in the loss of all data as soon as CAS is started. For transient data like tickets this is probably not an issue, but in cases like the audit table important data could be lost. Using `update`, while safe for data, is confirmed to result in invalid database state. {@code validate} or {@code none} settings are likely the only safe options for production use.

For more info, see this.

name: cas.authn.mfa.inwebo.failure-mode
description:
The failure mode policy for this MFA provider. The authentication policy by default supports fail-closed mode, which means that if you attempt to exercise a particular provider available to CAS and the provider cannot be reached, authentication will be stopped and an error will be displayed. You can of course change this behavior so that authentication proceeds without exercising the provider functionality, if that provider cannot respond. Each defined multifactor authentication provider can set its own failure mode policy. Failure modes set at this location will override the global failure mode, but defer to any failure mode set by the registered service. Available values are as follows:
  • {@code OPEN}: Disallow MFA, proceed with authentication but don't communicate MFA to the RP.
  • {@code CLOSED}: Disallow MFA, block with authentication.
  • {@code PHANTOM}: Disallow MFA, proceed with authentication and communicate MFA to the RP.
  • {@code NONE}: Do not check for failure at all.
  • {@code UNDEFINED}: The default one indicating that no failure mode is set at all.

  • {@code none}: No validation takes place.
  • {@code compare}: Validates a connection is healthy by performing a compare operation.

name: cas.authn.pac4j.oidc[].generic.include-access-token-claims
description:
If enabled, try to process the access token as a JWT and include its claims in the profile.
Only enable this if there is an agreement between the IdP and CAS about the format of

name: cas.authn.mfa.gauth.ldap.pool-passivator
description:
You may receive unexpected LDAP failures, when CAS is configured to authenticate using {@code DIRECT} or {@code AUTHENTICATED} types and LDAP is locked down to not allow anonymous binds/searches. Every second attempt with a given LDAP connection from the pool would fail if it was on the same connection as a failed login attempt, and the regular connection validator would similarly fail. When a connection is returned back to a pool, it still may contain the principal and credentials from the previous attempt. Before the next bind attempt using that connection, the validator tries to validate the connection again but fails because it’s no longer trying with the configured bind credentials but with whatever user DN was used in the previous step. Given the validation failure, the connection is closed and CAS would deny access by default. Passivators attempt to reconnect to LDAP with the configured bind credentials, effectively resetting the connection to what it should be after each bind request. Furthermore if you are seeing errors in the logs that resemble a 'Operation exception encountered, reopening connection' type of message, this usually is an indication that the connection pool’s validation timeout established and created by CAS is greater than the timeout configured in the LDAP server, or more likely, in the load balancer in front of the LDAP servers. You can adjust the LDAP server session’s timeout for connections, or you can teach CAS to use a validity period that is equal or less than the LDAP server session’s timeout. Accepted values are:
  • {@code NONE}: No passivation takes place.
  • {@code BIND}: The default behavior which passivates a connection by performing a bind operation on it. This option requires the availability of bind credentials when establishing connections to LDAP.

name: cas.authn.mfa.yubikey.dynamo-db.billing-mode
description:
Billing mode specifies how you are charged for read and write throughput and how you manage capacity. Available values are as follows:
  • {@code PROVISIONED}: Provisioned mode means that you specify the number of reads and writes per second that you expect your application to use. Provisioned mode is a good option if any of the following are true:
    • You have predictable application traffic.
    • You run applications whose traffic is consistent or ramps gradually.
    • You can forecast capacity requirements to control costs.
    You can use auto scaling to automatically adjust capacity based on the specified utilization rate to ensure application performance while reducing costs.
  • {@code PAY_PER_REQUEST}: Pay-per-request or on-demand billing means that you're charged for only the read/write requests that you use. On-demand mode is a good option if any of the following are true:
    • You create new tables with unknown workloads.
    • You have unpredictable application traffic.
    • You prefer the ease of paying for only what you use.
    Tables using on-demand mode support all DynamoDB features (such as encryption at rest, point-in-time recovery, global tables, and so on) with the exception of auto scaling, which is not applicable with this mode.

name: cas.authn.x509.ldap.base-dn

The user DN is retrieved using the combination of all base-dn and DN resolvers in the order defined. DN resolution should fail if multiple DNs are found. Otherwise the first DN found is returned. Usual syntax is: {@code subtreeA,dc=example,dc=net|subtreeC,dc=example,dc=net}.

If it is able to connect, it will now about all members in the cluster and doesn't rely on these well known members anymore.

name: cas.monitor.jdbc.ddl-auto
description:
Hibernate feature to automatically validate and exports DDL to the schema. By default, creates and drops the schema automatically when a session is starts and ends. Setting the value to {@code validate} or {@code none} may be more desirable for production, but any of the following options can be used:
  • {@code validate}: Validate the schema, but make no changes to the database.
  • {@code update}: Update the schema.
  • {@code create}: Create the schema, destroying previous data.
  • {@code create-drop}: Drop the schema at the end of the session.
  • {@code none}: Do nothing.

Note that during a version migration where any schema has changed {@code create-drop} will result in the loss of all data as soon as CAS is started. For transient data like tickets this is probably not an issue, but in cases like the audit table important data could be lost. Using `update`, while safe for data, is confirmed to result in invalid database state. {@code validate} or {@code none} settings are likely the only safe options for production use.

For more info, see this.

name: cas.authn.cloud-directory.password-encoder.type
description:
Define the password encoder type to use. Type may be specified as blank or {@code NONE} to disable password encoding. It may also refer to a fully-qualified class name that implements the Spring Security's {@code PasswordEncoder} interface if you wish you define your own encoder.

The following types may be used:

  • {@code NONE}: No password encoding (i.e. plain-text) takes place.
  • {@code DEFAULT}: Use the {@code DefaultPasswordEncoder} of CAS. For message-digest algorithms via {@code character-encoding} and {@code encoding-algorithm}.
  • {@code BCRYPT}: Use the {@code BCryptPasswordEncoder} based on the strength provided and an optional secret.
  • {@code SCRYPT}: Use the {@code SCryptPasswordEncoder}.
  • {@code PBKDF2}: Use the {@code Pbkdf2PasswordEncoder} based on the strength provided and an optional secret.
  • {@code STANDARD}: Use the {@code StandardPasswordEncoder} based on the secret provided.
  • {@code SSHA}: Use the {@code LdapShaPasswordEncoder} supports Ldap SHA and SSHA (salted-SHA). The values are base-64 encoded and have the label {SHA} or {SSHA} prepended to the encoded hash.
  • {@code GLIBC_CRYPT}: Use the {@code GlibcCryptPasswordEncoder} based on the {@code encoding-algorithm}, strength provided and an optional secret.
  • {@code org.example.MyEncoder}: An implementation of {@code PasswordEncoder} of your own choosing.
  • {@code file:///path/to/script.groovy}: Path to a Groovy script charged with handling password encoding operations.

name: cas.authn.jdbc.encode[].fail-fast-timeout
description:
Set the pool initialization failure timeout.
  • Any value greater than zero will be treated as a timeout for pool initialization. The calling thread will be blocked from continuing until a successful connection to the database, or until the timeout is reached. If the timeout is reached, then a {@code PoolInitializationException} will be thrown.
  • A value of zero will not prevent the pool from starting in the case that a connection cannot be obtained. However, upon start the pool will attempt to obtain a connection and validate that the {@code connectionTestQuery} and {@code connectionInitSql} are valid. If those validations fail, an exception will be thrown. If a connection cannot be obtained, the validation is skipped and the the pool will start and continue to try to obtain connections in the background. This can mean that callers to {@code DataSource#getConnection()} may encounter exceptions.
  • A value less than zero will not bypass any connection attempt and validation during startup, and therefore the pool will start immediately. The pool will continue to try to obtain connections in the background. This can mean that callers to {@code DataSource#getConnection()} may encounter exceptions.
Note that if this timeout value is greater than or equal to zero (0), and therefore an initial connection validation is performed, this timeout does not override the {@code connectionTimeout} or {@code validationTimeout}; they will be honored before this timeout is applied. The default value is one millisecond.

name: cas.authn.throttle.ldap.pool-passivator
description:
You may receive unexpected LDAP failures, when CAS is configured to authenticate using {@code DIRECT} or {@code AUTHENTICATED} types and LDAP is locked down to not allow anonymous binds/searches. Every second attempt with a given LDAP connection from the pool would fail if it was on the same connection as a failed login attempt, and the regular connection validator would similarly fail. When a connection is returned back to a pool, it still may contain the principal and credentials from the previous attempt. Before the next bind attempt using that connection, the validator tries to validate the connection again but fails because it’s no longer trying with the configured bind credentials but with whatever user DN was used in the previous step. Given the validation failure, the connection is closed and CAS would deny access by default. Passivators attempt to reconnect to LDAP with the configured bind credentials, effectively resetting the connection to what it should be after each bind request. Furthermore if you are seeing errors in the logs that resemble a 'Operation exception encountered, reopening connection' type of message, this usually is an indication that the connection pool’s validation timeout established and created by CAS is greater than the timeout configured in the LDAP server, or more likely, in the load balancer in front of the LDAP servers. You can adjust the LDAP server session’s timeout for connections, or you can teach CAS to use a validity period that is equal or less than the LDAP server session’s timeout. Accepted values are:
  • {@code NONE}: No passivation takes place.
  • {@code BIND}: The default behavior which passivates a connection by performing a bind operation on it. This option requires the availability of bind credentials when establishing connections to LDAP.

name: cas.saml-sp.tableau.signature-location
description: Signature location used to verify metadata.

name: cas.authn.accept.password-policy.login-failures
description: When dealing with FreeIPA, indicates the number of allows login failures.

name: cas.authn.mfa.authy.phone-attribute
description: Principal attribute used to look up a phone number for credential verification. The attribute value is then used to look up the user record in Authy, or create the user.

name: cas.service-registry.redis.pool.num-tests-per-eviction-run
description: Sets the maximum number of objects to examine during each run (if any) of the idle object evictor thread. When positive, the number of tests performed for a run will be the minimum of the configured value and the number of idle instances in the pool. When negative, the number of tests performed will be ceil(getNumIdle()/ abs(getNumTestsPerEvictionRun())) which means that when the value is -n roughly one nth of the idle objects will be tested per run.

name: cas.monitor.mongo[].pool.max-wait-time

name: cas.audit.dynamo-db.prevent-table-creation-on-startup

name: cas.authn.saml-idp.metadata.rest.crypto.encryption.key

name: cas.authn.mfa.gauth.redis.cluster.nodes[].host

name: cas.authn.pac4j.twitter.client-name

This name, with 'non-word' characters converted to '-' (e.g. "This Org (New)" becomes "This-Org--New-") is added to the "class" attribute of the redirect link on the login page, to allow for custom styling of individual IdPs (e.g. for an organization logo).

name: cas.authn.pac4j.profile-selection.ldap.disable-pooling

name: cas.service-registry.stream.hazelcast.config.cluster.discovery.kubernetes.api-token

name: cas.authn.pm.ldap[].sasl-quality-of-protection
description: SASL quality of protected.

name: cas.authn.ldap[].principal-attribute-list
description:
List of attributes to retrieve from LDAP. Attributes can be virtually remapped to multiple names. Example {@code cn:commonName,givenName,eduPersonTargettedId:SOME_IDENTIFIER}.

To fetch and resolve attributes that carry tags/options, consider tagging the mapped attribute as such: {@code homePostalAddress:homePostalAddress;}.

name: cas.saml-sp.safari-online.description

name: cas.sso.sso-enabled

name: cas.saml-sp.net-partner.sign-assertions

name: cas.interrupt.regex.attribute-value
description: A regex pattern on the attribute value that if matches will successfully complete the first condition for the interrupt notifications trigger.

name: cas.service-registry.cassandra.local-dc
description: Used by a DC-ware round-robin load balancing policy. This policy provides round-robin queries over the node of the local data center. It also includes in the query plans returned a configurable number of hosts in the remote data centers, but those are always tried after the local nodes. In other words, this policy guarantees that no host in a remote data center will be queried unless no host in the local data center can be reached.

name: cas.authn.mfa.yubikey.crypto.enabled
description: Whether crypto operations are enabled.

name: cas.message-bundle.fallback-system-locale
description: Flag that controls whether to fallback to the default system locale if no locale is specified explicitly. Set whether to fall back to the system Locale if no files for a specific Locale have been found. If this is turned off, the only fallback will be the default file (e.g. "messages.properties" for basename "messages"). Falling back to the system Locale is the default behavior of {@link java.util.ResourceBundle}. However, this is often not desirable in an application server environment, where the system Locale is not relevant to the application at all: set this flag to {@code false} in such a scenario.

name: cas.ticket.registry.redis.cluster.nodes[].id
description: Identifier of this node.

name: cas.authn.attribute-repository.ldap[].ldap-url

name: cas.authn.pac4j.google.principal-id-attribute

name: cas.consent.core.webflow.enabled

name: cas.saml-sp.cher-well.sign-responses

name: cas.saml-sp.egnyte.name-id-format

name: cas.authn.mfa.yubikey.redis.pool.test-while-idle
description: Returns whether objects sitting idle in the pool will be validated by the idle object evictor ( if any - see setTimeBetweenEvictionRunsMillis(long)). Validation is performed by the validateObject() method of the factory associated with the pool. If the object fails to validate, it will be removed from the pool and destroyed.

name: cas.monitor.ldap[].idle-time

Removes connections from the pool based on how long they have been idle in the available queue.
Prunes connections that have been idle for more than the indicated amount.

name: cas.authn.pac4j.bitbucket.principal-id-attribute

name: cas.authn.attribute-repository.jdbc[].pool.max-wait
description:
Sets the maximum time in seconds that this data source will wait while attempting to connect to a database.

A value of zero specifies that the timeout is the default system timeout if there is one; otherwise, it specifies that there is no timeout.

name: cas.authn.attribute-repository.redis[].cluster.nodes.host
description: Server's host address.

name: cas.authn.pm.jdbc.driver-class

name: cas.server.name
description: Full name of the CAS server. This is the public-facing address of the CAS deployment and not the individual node address, in the event that CAS is clustered.

name: cas.authn.jdbc.query[].isolate-internal-queries
description:
This property determines whether data source isolates internal pool queries, such as the connection alive test, in their own transaction.

Since these are typically read-only queries, it is rarely necessary to encapsulate them in their own transaction. This property only applies if {@link #autocommit} is disabled.

name: cas.service-registry.mail.from
description: Email from address.

name: cas.saml-sp.zendesk.name
description: Name of this service provider.

name: cas.authn.azure-active-directory.principal-transformation.pattern

name: cas.authn.mfa.gauth.jpa.url

name: cas.authn.pac4j.oidc[].apple.enabled

Whether the client/external identity provider should be considered
active and enabled for integration purposes.

name: cas.audit.mongo.pool.min-size
description: Minimum number of connections to keep around.

name: cas.saml-sp.salesforce.attributes
description: Set up the attribute release policy for this service. Allow attributes that are to be released to this SP. Attributes should be separated by commas and can be virtually mapped and renamed.

name: cas.authn.cognito.mapped-attributes
description: Map of attributes to rename after fetching from the user pool. Mapped attributes are defined using a key-value structure where CAS allows the attribute name/key to be renamed virtually to a different attribute. The key is the attribute fetched from the user pool and the value is the attribute name CAS should use for virtual renames.

name: cas.authn.pm.core.auto-login
description: Flag to indicate whether successful password change should trigger login automatically.

name: cas.audit.mongo.pool.idle-time
description: The maximum idle time of a pooled connection.  A zero value indicates no limit to the idle time.  A pooled connection that has exceeded its idle time will be closed and replaced when necessary by a new connection.

name: cas.authn.mfa.web-authn.redis.read-from
description:
Setting that describes how Lettuce routes read operations to replica nodes. Note that modes referencing MASTER/SLAVE are deprecated (but still supported) in the Lettuce redis client dependency so migrate config to UPSTREAM/REPLICA. Available values are as follows:
  • {@code UPSTREAM}: Read from the current upstream node.
  • {@code UPSTREAMPREFERRED}: Read from the upstream node, but if it is unavailable, read from replica nodes.
  • {@code MASTER}: Read from the current upstream node.
  • {@code MASTERPREFERRED}: Read from the upstream node, but if it is unavailable, read from replica nodes.
  • {@code SLAVE}: Read from replica nodes.
  • {@code SLAVEPREFERRED}: Read from the replica nodes, but if none is unavailable, read from the upstream node.
  • {@code REPLICA}: Read from replica nodes.
  • {@code REPLICAPREFERRED}: Read from the replica nodes, but if none is unavailable, read from the upstream node.
  • {@code ANY}: Read from any node of the cluster.
  • {@code ANYREPLICA}: Read from any replica node of the cluster.
  • {@code NEAREST}: Read from the nearest node.

name: cas.authn.mfa.u2f.core.bypass.rest.url
description: The endpoint URL to contact and retrieve attributes.

name: cas.monitor.ldap[].prune-period
description:
Removes connections from the pool based on how long they have been idle in the available queue.
Run the pruning process at the indicated interval.

name: cas.webflow.session.server.hazelcast.cluster.discovery.azure.client-id
description: The Azure Active Directory Service Principal client ID.

name: cas.authn.oidc.jwks.mongo.client-uri
description: The connection uri to the mongodb instance. This typically takes on the form of {@code mongodb://user:psw@ds135522.somewhere.com:35522/db}. If not specified, will fallback onto other individual settings. If specified, takes over all other settings where applicable.

name: cas.authn.spnego.ldap.follow-referrals
description: Set if search referrals should be followed.

name: cas.authn.azure-active-directory.client-secret
description: Client secret of the registered app in microsoft azure portal.

name: cas.authn.x509.ldap.search-entry-handlers[].dn-attribute.add-if-exists
description: The Add if exists.

name: cas.authn.gua.ldap.allow-multiple-entries
description: Set if multiple Entries are allowed.

name: cas.monitor.memcached.kryo-auto-reset
description: If true, {@code reset} is called automatically after an entire object graph has been read or written. If false, {@code reset} must be called manually, which allows unregistered class names, references, and other information to span multiple object graphs.

name: cas.authn.jdbc.search[].password-encoder.iterations
description: When used by {@link PasswordEncoderTypes#PBKDF2}, it indicates the required number of iterations.

name: cas.authn.token.crypto.encryption-enabled
description: Whether crypto encryption operations are enabled.

name: cas.authn.mfa.yubikey.redis.protocol-version
description: Redis protocol version.

name: cas.authn.oauth.crypto.signing.key-size
description: The signing key size.

name: cas.authn.throttle.hazelcast.cluster.discovery.aws.connection-timeout-seconds
description: The maximum amount of time Hazelcast will try to connect to a well known member before giving up. Setting this value too low could mean that a member is not able to connect to a cluster. Setting the value too high means that member startup could slow down because of longer timeouts (for example, when a well known member is not up). Increasing this value is recommended if you have many IPs listed and the members cannot properly build up the cluster. Its default value is 5.

name: cas.authn.mfa.gauth.ldap.search-entry-handlers[].dn-attribute.add-if-exists
description: The Add if exists.

name: cas.locale.cookie.name
description: Cookie name. Constructs a cookie with a specified name and value. The name must conform to RFC 2965. That means it can contain only ASCII alphanumeric characters and cannot contain commas, semicolons, or white space or begin with a {@code $} character. The cookie's name cannot be changed after creation. By default, cookies are created according to the RFC 2965 cookie specification. Cookie names are automatically calculated assigned by CAS at runtime, and there is usually no need to customize the name or assign it a different value unless a special use case warrants the change.

name: cas.account-registration.core.include-client-ip-address
description: Whether the registration token will contain the client IP Address.

name: cas.authn.jaas[].principal-transformation.case-conversion
description:
Indicate whether the principal identifier should be transformed into upper-case, lower-case, etc. Available values are as follows:
  • {@code NONE}: No conversion.
  • {@code LOWERCASE}: Lowercase conversion.
  • {@code UPPERCASE}: Uppercase conversion.

name: cas.authn.mfa.authy.api-key
description: Authy API key.

name: cas.authn.mfa.simple.token.bypass.authentication-attribute-value
description: Optionally, skip multifactor authentication based on designated authentication attribute values.

name: cas.service-registry.git.timeout
description: Timeout for git operations such as push and pull in seconds.

name: cas.authn.throttle.hazelcast.cluster.core.backup-count
description: To provide data safety, Hazelcast allows you to specify the number of backup copies you want to have. That way, data on a cluster member will be copied onto other member(s). To create synchronous backups, select the number of backup copies. When this count is 1, a map entry will have its backup on one other member in the cluster. If you set it to 2, then a map entry will have its backup on two other members. You can set it to 0 if you do not want your entries to be backed up, e.g., if performance is more important than backing up. The maximum value for the backup count is 6. Sync backup operations have a blocking cost which may lead to latency issues.

name: cas.saml-sp.sans-sth.signature-location
description: Signature location used to verify metadata.

name: cas.authn.jdbc.query[].credential-criteria
description:
A number of authentication handlers are allowed to determine whether they can operate on the provided credential and as such lend themselves to be tried and tested during the authentication handler selection phase. The credential criteria may be one of the following options:
  • 1) A regular expression pattern that is tested against the credential identifier.
  • 2) A fully qualified class name of your own design that implements {@code Predicate}.
  • 3) Path to an external Groovy script that implements the same interface.

name: cas.authn.mfa.gauth.bypass.groovy.location
description:
The location of the resource. Resources can be URLs, or files found either on the classpath or outside somewhere in the file system.

In the event the configured resource is a Groovy script, specially if the script set to reload on changes, you may need to adjust the total number of {@code inotify} instances. On Linux, you may need to add the following line to {@code /etc/sysctl.conf}: {@code fs.inotify.max_user_instances = 256}.

You can check the current value via {@code cat /proc/sys/fs/inotify/max_user_instances}.

name: cas.authn.oauth.core.user-profile-view-type
description:
User profile view type determines how the final user profile should be rendered once an access token is "validated". Available values are as follows:
  • {@code NESTED}: Return and render the user profile view in nested mode. This is the default option, most usually.
  • {@code FLAT}: Return and render the user profile view in flattened mode where all attributes are flattened down to one level only.

name: cas.authn.mfa.web-authn.ldap.sasl-realm
description: The SASL realm.

name: cas.authn.oidc.jwks.jpa.pool.maximum-lifetime
description: This property controls the maximum lifetime of a connection in the pool. When a connection reaches this timeout, even if recently used, it will be retired from the pool. An in-use connection will never be retired, only when it is idle will it be removed.

name: cas.ticket.registry.dynamo-db.crypto.alg
description: The signing/encryption algorithm to use.

name: cas.saml-sp.jira.entity-ids
description: List of entityIds allowed for this service provider. Multiple ids can be specified in the event that the metadata is an aggregate.

name: cas.saml-sp.zoom.name
description: Name of this service provider.

name: cas.authn.mfa.yubikey.redis.scan-count
description: Redis scan count option. When and if specified, SCAN operations would be "counted" or limited by this serting. While SCAN does not provide guarantees about the number of elements returned at every iteration, it is possible to empirically adjust the behavior of SCAN using the COUNT option. Basically with COUNT the user specified the amount of work that should be done at every call in order to retrieve elements from the collection. This is just a hint for the implementation, however generally speaking this is what you could expect most of the times from the implementation.

name: cas.service-registry.cosmos-db.user-agent-suffix
description: Sets the value of the user-agent suffix.

name: cas.ticket.registry.memcached.timeout-exception-threshold
description: Set the maximum timeout exception threshold.

name: cas.authn.surrogate.ldap.subtree-search
description: Whether subtree searching is allowed.

name: cas.monitor.ldap[].keystore-password
description: Keystore password.

name: cas.authn.oauth.session-replication.cookie.name
description: Cookie name. Constructs a cookie with a specified name and value. The name must conform to RFC 2965. That means it can contain only ASCII alphanumeric characters and cannot contain commas, semicolons, or white space or begin with a {@code $} character. The cookie's name cannot be changed after creation. By default, cookies are created according to the RFC 2965 cookie specification. Cookie names are automatically calculated assigned by CAS at runtime, and there is usually no need to customize the name or assign it a different value unless a special use case warrants the change.

name: cas.authn.throttle.hazelcast.cluster.discovery.aws.security-group-name
description: If a security group is configured, only instances within that security group are selected.

name: cas.webflow.session.server.hazelcast.cluster.discovery.docker-swarm.member-provider.docker-network-names
description: Comma delimited list of Docker network names to discover matching services on.

name: cas.authn.pac4j.saml[].metadata.service-provider.mongo.ssl-enabled
description: Whether connections require SSL.

name: cas.saml-sp.docu-sign.sign-assertions
description: Indicate whether assertions should be signed.

name: cas.authn.ldap[].password-policy.display-warning-on-match
description:
Indicates if warning should be displayed, when the ldap attribute value
matches the {@link #warningAttributeValue}.

name: cas.authn.spnego.ldap.sasl-realm
description: The SASL realm.

name: cas.service-registry.sms.attribute-name
description: Principal attribute name that indicates the destination phone number for this SMS message. The attribute must already be resolved and available to the CAS principal.

name: cas.authn.redis.share-native-connections
description: The shared native connection is never closed by Lettuce connection, therefore it is not validated by default when connections are retrieved. If this setting is {@code true}, a shared connection will be used for regular operations and a connection provider will be used to select a connection for blocking and tx operations only, which should not share a connection. If native connection sharing is disabled, new (or pooled) connections will be used for all operations. By default, multiple connections share a single thread-safe native connection. If you enable connection pooling, then native connection sharing will be disabled and the connection pool will be used for all operations. You may however explicitly control connection sharing via this setting as an override.

name: cas.webflow.session.server.hazelcast.cluster.discovery.kubernetes.api-retries
description: Defines the number of retries to Kubernetes API. Defaults to: 3.

name: cas.authn.mfa.inwebo.bypass.authentication-method-name
description: Skip multifactor authentication depending on method/form of primary authentication execution. Specifically, skip multifactor if the authentication method attribute collected as part of authentication metadata matches a certain value.

name: cas.authn.mfa.trusted.mongo.socket-keep-alive
description: Whether the database socket connection should be tagged with keep-alive.

name: cas.authn.passwordless.accounts.ldap.trust-manager
description:
Trust Manager options. Trust managers are responsible for managing the trust material that is used when making LDAP trust decisions, and for deciding whether credentials presented by a peer should be accepted. Accepted values are: *
  • {@code DEFAULT}: Enable and force the default JVM trust managers.
  • {@code ANY}: Trust any client or server.

name: cas.authn.pac4j.cas[].login-url

name: cas.authn.mfa.gauth.mongo.pool.idle-time
description: The maximum idle time of a pooled connection.  A zero value indicates no limit to the idle time.  A pooled connection that has exceeded its idle time will be closed and replaced when necessary by a new connection.

name: cas.authn.passwordless.accounts.mongo.pool.idle-time
description: The maximum idle time of a pooled connection.  A zero value indicates no limit to the idle time.  A pooled connection that has exceeded its idle time will be closed and replaced when necessary by a new connection.

name: cas.authn.throttle.jdbc.user

The database user.

The database user must have sufficient permissions to be able to handle schema changes and updates, when needed.

name: cas.authn.pac4j.core.session-replication.cookie.crypto.enabled
description: Whether crypto operations are enabled.

name: cas.authn.oidc.jwks.jpa.properties
description: Additional settings provided by Hibernate (or the connection provider) in form of key-value pairs.

name: cas.authn.surrogate.ldap.max-pool-size
description: Maximum LDAP connection pool size which the pool can use to grow.

name: cas.saml-sp.workday.sign-responses

description: Keystore password.

description: The Dn attribute name.

description: List of attributes that should be retrieved from LDAP for this profile.

name: cas.authn.attribute-repository.syncope.basic-auth-username
description: Specify the username for REST authentication.

description: The JDBC driver used to connect to the database.

name: cas.authn.pac4j.wordpress.css-class

name: cas.saml-metadata-ui.require-valid-metadata
description: Whether valid metadata is required when parsing metadata.

name: cas.monitor.mongo[].write-concern
description:
Write concern describes the level of acknowledgement requested from
MongoDB for write operations to a standalone
mongo db or to replica sets or to sharded clusters. In sharded clusters,
mongo db instances will pass the write concern on to the shards.

name: cas.authn.adaptive.risk.agent.enabled
description: Enable user-agent checking and criteria to calculate risky authentication attempts.

name: cas.authn.oidc.discovery.introspection-supported-authentication-methods
description: Supported authentication methods for introspection.

name: cas.saml-core.attribute-namespace
description: Attribute namespace to use when generating SAML1 responses.

name: cas.authn.mfa.yubikey.redis.sentinel.node
description: list of host:port pairs.

name: cas.authn.surrogate.simple.prune-period
description: Removes connections from the pool based on how long they have been idle in the available queue. Run the pruning process at the indicated interval.

name: cas.authn.throttle.hazelcast.cluster.discovery.kubernetes.use-node-name-as-external-address
description: Defines if the node name should be used as external address, instead of looking up the external IP using the {@code /nodes} resource. Default is false.

name: cas.service-registry.amazon-s3.client-execution-timeout
description: Client execution timeout.

name: cas.saml-sp.zendesk.name-id-format
description: The forced nameId format to use when generating a response.

name: cas.amazon-sts.max-connections
description: Maximum connections setting.

name: cas.consent.jpa.default-schema
description: Qualify unqualified table names with the given schema/tablespace in generated SQL.

name: cas.ticket.registry.hazelcast.cluster.core.logging-type
description:
Hazelcast has a flexible logging configuration and doesn't depend on any logging framework except JDK logging. It has in-built adaptors for a number of logging frameworks and also supports custom loggers by providing logging interfaces. To use built-in adaptors you should set this setting to one of predefined types below.
  • {@code jdk}: JDK logging
  • {@code log4j}: Log4j
  • {@code slf4j}: Slf4j
  • {@code none}: Disable logging

name: cas.saml-sp.egnyte.sign-assertions
description: Indicate whether assertions should be signed.

name: cas.authn.mfa.trusted.jpa.generate-statistics

name: cas.authn.throttle.jdbc.autocommit
description: The default auto-commit behavior of connections in the pool. Determined whether queries such as update/insert should be immediately executed without waiting for an underlying transaction.

name: cas.authn.jdbc.bind[].url
description: The database connection URL.

name: cas.saml-sp.open-athens.name
description: Name of this service provider.

name: cas.monitor.ldap[].pool.suspension
description:
Whether or not pool suspension is allowed.

There is a performance impact when pool suspension is enabled. Unless you need it (for a redundancy system for example) do not enable it.

name: cas.consent.ldap.validate-periodically
description: Whether connections should be validated periodically when the pool is idle.

name: cas.authn.jdbc.search[].password-encoder.hash-length

description: The Attribute names.

name: cas.audit.engine.supported-actions
description: Indicate a list of supported audit actions that should be recognized, processed and recorded by CAS audit managers. Each supported action can be treated as a regular expression to match against built-in CAS actions.

name: cas.ticket.registry.core.enable-locking
description: When set to true, registry operations will begin to support distributed locking for ticket operations. If the registry itself supports distributed locking, such as JDBC or Redis, then the lock implementation will defer to that option. Otherwise the default locking solution will be specific to a CAS server node, until replaced with a lock implementation or different locking option separate from the registry technology itself.

On Linux, you may need to add the following line to {@code /etc/sysctl.conf}: {@code fs.inotify.max_user_instances = 256}.

name: cas.ticket.registry.dynamo-db.billing-mode
description:
Billing mode specifies how you are charged for read and write throughput and how you manage capacity. Available values are as follows:
  • {@code PROVISIONED}: Provisioned mode means that you specify the number of reads and writes per second that you expect your application to use. Provisioned mode is a good option if any of the following are true:
    • You have predictable application traffic.
    • You run applications whose traffic is consistent or ramps gradually.
    • You can forecast capacity requirements to control costs.
    You can use auto scaling to automatically adjust capacity based on the specified utilization rate to ensure application performance while reducing costs.
  • {@code PAY_PER_REQUEST}: Pay-per-request or on-demand billing means that you're charged for only the read/write requests that you use. On-demand mode is a good option if any of the following are true:
    • You create new tables with unknown workloads.
    • You have unpredictable application traffic.
    • You prefer the ease of paying for only what you use.
    Tables using on-demand mode support all DynamoDB features (such as encryption at rest, point-in-time recovery, global tables, and so on) with the exception of auto scaling, which is not applicable with this mode.

name: cas.authn.attribute-repository.jdbc[].health-query

name: cas.authn.x509.subject-alt-name.alternate-principal-attribute

Attribute name that will be used by X509 principal resolvers if the main attribute in the certificate is not present. This only applies to principal resolvers that are looking for attributes in the certificate that are not common to all certificates. (e.g. {@code SUBJECT_ALT_NAME}, {@code CN_EDIPI})

This assumes you would rather get something like the {@code subjectDn} rather than {@code null} where {@code null} would allow falling through to another authentication mechanism.

Currently supported values are: {@code subjectDn}, {@code sigAlgOid}, {@code subjectX500Principal}.

  • {@code DENY}: Deny authentication and block.
  • {@code THRESHOLD}: Applicable to CRL expiration, throttle the request whereby expired data is permitted up to a threshold period of time but not afterward.

name: cas.events.redis.share-native-connections
description: The shared native connection is never closed by Lettuce connection, therefore it is not validated by default when connections are retrieved. If this setting is {@code true}, a shared connection will be used for regular operations and a connection provider will be used to select a connection for blocking and tx operations only, which should not share a connection. If native connection sharing is disabled, new (or pooled) connections will be used for all operations. By default, multiple connections share a single thread-safe native connection. If you enable connection pooling, then native connection sharing will be disabled and the connection pool will be used for all operations. You may however explicitly control connection sharing via this setting as an override.

name: cas.authn.accept.password-encoder.type
description:
Define the password encoder type to use. Type may be specified as blank or {@code NONE} to disable password encoding. It may also refer to a fully-qualified class name that implements the Spring Security's {@code PasswordEncoder} interface if you wish you define your own encoder.

The following types may be used:

  • {@code NONE}: No password encoding (i.e. plain-text) takes place.
  • {@code DEFAULT}: Use the {@code DefaultPasswordEncoder} of CAS. For message-digest algorithms via {@code character-encoding} and {@code encoding-algorithm}.
  • {@code BCRYPT}: Use the {@code BCryptPasswordEncoder} based on the strength provided and an optional secret.
  • {@code SCRYPT}: Use the {@code SCryptPasswordEncoder}.
  • {@code PBKDF2}: Use the {@code Pbkdf2PasswordEncoder} based on the strength provided and an optional secret.
  • {@code STANDARD}: Use the {@code StandardPasswordEncoder} based on the secret provided.
  • {@code SSHA}: Use the {@code LdapShaPasswordEncoder} supports Ldap SHA and SSHA (salted-SHA). The values are base-64 encoded and have the label {SHA} or {SSHA} prepended to the encoded hash.
  • {@code GLIBC_CRYPT}: Use the {@code GlibcCryptPasswordEncoder} based on the {@code encoding-algorithm}, strength provided and an optional secret.
  • {@code org.example.MyEncoder}: An implementation of {@code PasswordEncoder} of your own choosing.
  • {@code file:///path/to/script.groovy}: Path to a Groovy script charged with handling password encoding operations.

name: cas.ticket.registry.hazelcast.cluster.discovery.multicast.port
description: The multicast port used for discovery.

name: cas.authn.pac4j.core.session-replication.cookie.path
description: Cookie path. Specifies a path for the cookie to which the client should return the cookie. The cookie is visible to all the pages in the directory you specify, and all the pages in that directory's subdirectories. A cookie's path must include the servlet that set the cookie, for example, /catalog, which makes the cookie visible to all directories on the server under /catalog. Consult RFC 2965 (available on the Internet) for more information on setting path names for cookies.
