name: cas.authn.mfa.gauth.rank
description:
At times, CAS needs to determine the correct provider when step-up authentication is required. Consider for a moment that CAS already has established an SSO session with/without a provider and has reached a level of authentication. Another incoming request attempts to exercise that SSO session with a different and often competing authentication requirement that may differ from the authentication level CAS has already established. Concretely, examples may be:
  • CAS has achieved an SSO session, but a separate request now requires step-up authentication with DuoSecurity.
  • CAS has achieved an SSO session with an authentication level satisfied by DuoSecurity, but a separate request now requires step-up authentication with YubiKey.
In certain scenarios, CAS will attempt to rank authentication levels and compare them with each other. If CAS already has achieved a level that is higher than what the incoming request requires, no step-up authentication will be performed. If the opposite is true, CAS will route the authentication flow to the required authentication level and upon success, will adjust the SSO session with the new higher authentication level now satisfied. Ranking of authentication methods is done per provider via specific properties for each. Note that the higher the rank value is, the higher on the security scale it remains. A provider that ranks higher with a larger weight value trumps and override others with a lower value.

name: cas.authn.passwordless.tokens.jpa.fail-fast-timeout
description:
Set the pool initialization failure timeout.
  • Any value greater than zero will be treated as a timeout for pool initialization. The calling thread will be blocked from continuing until a successful connection to the database, or until the timeout is reached. If the timeout is reached, then a {@code PoolInitializationException} will be thrown.
  • A value of zero will not prevent the pool from starting in the case that a connection cannot be obtained. However, upon start the pool will attempt to obtain a connection and validate that the {@code connectionTestQuery} and {@code connectionInitSql} are valid. If those validations fail, an exception will be thrown. If a connection cannot be obtained, the validation is skipped and the the pool will start and continue to try to obtain connections in the background. This can mean that callers to {@code DataSource#getConnection()} may encounter exceptions.
  • A value less than zero will not bypass any connection attempt and validation during startup, and therefore the pool will start immediately. The pool will continue to try to obtain connections in the background. This can mean that callers to {@code DataSource#getConnection()} may encounter exceptions.
Note that if this timeout value is greater than or equal to zero (0), and therefore an initial connection validation is performed, this timeout does not override the {@code connectionTimeout} or {@code validationTimeout}; they will be honored before this timeout is applied. The default value is one millisecond.

name: cas.webflow.session.server.hazelcast.cluster.discovery.aws.connection-timeout-seconds
description: The maximum amount of time Hazelcast will try to connect to a well known member before giving up. Setting this value too low could mean that a member is not able to connect to a cluster. Setting the value too high means that member startup could slow down because of longer timeouts (for example, when a well known member is not up). Increasing this value is recommended if you have many IPs listed and the members cannot properly build up the cluster. Its default value is 5.

You can check the current value via {@code cat /proc/sys/fs/inotify/max_user_instances}.

name: cas.authn.oidc.core.issuer
description:
OIDC issuer. All OpenID Connect servers such as CAS are uniquely identified by a URL known as the issuer. This URL serves as the prefix of a service discovery endpoint as specified in the OpenID Connect Discovery standard.

This URL must be using the https scheme with no query or fragment component that the identity provider (CAS) asserts as its Issuer Identifier. This also MUST be identical to the {@code iss} claim value in ID Tokens issued from this issuer, unless overridden in very special circumstances as a last resort.

CAS primarily supports a single issuer per deployment/host.

name: cas.authn.redis.password-encoder.type
description:
Define the password encoder type to use. Type may be specified as blank or {@code NONE} to disable password encoding. It may also refer to a fully-qualified class name that implements the Spring Security's {@code PasswordEncoder} interface if you wish you define your own encoder.

The following types may be used:

  • {@code NONE}: No password encoding (i.e. plain-text) takes place.
  • {@code DEFAULT}: Use the {@code DefaultPasswordEncoder} of CAS. For message-digest algorithms via {@code character-encoding} and {@code encoding-algorithm}.
  • {@code BCRYPT}: Use the {@code BCryptPasswordEncoder} based on the strength provided and an optional secret.
  • {@code SCRYPT}: Use the {@code SCryptPasswordEncoder}.
  • {@code PBKDF2}: Use the {@code Pbkdf2PasswordEncoder} based on the strength provided and an optional secret.
  • {@code STANDARD}: Use the {@code StandardPasswordEncoder} based on the secret provided.
  • {@code SSHA}: Use the {@code LdapShaPasswordEncoder} supports Ldap SHA and SSHA (salted-SHA). The values are base-64 encoded and have the label {SHA} or {SSHA} prepended to the encoded hash.
  • {@code GLIBC_CRYPT}: Use the {@code GlibcCryptPasswordEncoder} based on the {@code encoding-algorithm}, strength provided and an optional secret.
  • {@code org.example.MyEncoder}: An implementation of {@code PasswordEncoder} of your own choosing.
  • {@code file:///path/to/script.groovy}: Path to a Groovy script charged with handling password encoding operations.

name: cas.authn.mfa.yubikey.redis.pool.num-tests-per-eviction-run
description: Sets the maximum number of objects to examine during each run (if any) of the idle object evictor thread. When positive, the number of tests performed for a run will be the minimum of the configured value and the number of idle instances in the pool. When negative, the number of tests performed will be ceil(getNumIdle()/ abs(getNumTestsPerEvictionRun())) which means that when the value is -n roughly one nth of the idle objects will be tested per run.

description:
Set the pool initialization failure timeout.
  • Any value greater than zero will be treated as a timeout for pool initialization. The calling thread will be blocked from continuing until a successful connection to the database, or until the timeout is reached. If the timeout is reached, then a {@code PoolInitializationException} will be thrown.
  • A value of zero will not prevent the pool from starting in the case that a connection cannot be obtained. However, upon start the pool will attempt to obtain a connection and validate that the {@code connectionTestQuery} and {@code connectionInitSql} are valid. If those validations fail, an exception will be thrown. If a connection cannot be obtained, the validation is skipped and the the pool will start and continue to try to obtain connections in the background.   • A value less than zero will not bypass any connection attempt and validation during startup, and therefore the pool will start immediately. The pool will continue to try to obtain connections in the background. This can mean that callers to {@code DataSource#getConnection()} may encounter exceptions.
Note that if this timeout value is greater than or equal to zero (0), and therefore an initial connection validation is performed, this timeout does not override the {@code connectionTimeout} or {@code validationTimeout}; they will be honored before this timeout is applied. name: cas.events.redis.read-from
description:
Setting that describes how Lettuce routes read operations to replica nodes. Note that modes referencing MASTER/SLAVE are deprecated (but still supported) in the Lettuce redis client dependency so migrate config to UPSTREAM/REPLICA. Available values are as follows:
  • {@code UPSTREAM}: Read from the current upstream node.
  • {@code UPSTREAMPREFERRED}: Read from the upstream node, but if it is unavailable, read from replica nodes.
  • {@code MASTER}: Read from the current upstream node.
  • {@code MASTERPREFERRED}: Read from the upstream node, but if it is unavailable, read from replica nodes.
  • {@code SLAVE}: Read from replica nodes.
  • {@code SLAVEPREFERRED}: Read from the replica nodes, but if none is unavailable, read from the upstream node.
  • {@code REPLICA}: Read from replica nodes.
  • {@code REPLICAPREFERRED}: Read from the replica nodes, but if none is unavailable, read from the upstream node.
  • {@code ANY}: Read from any node of the cluster.
  • {@code ANYREPLICA}: Read from any replica node of the cluster.
  • {@code NEAREST}: Read from the nearest node.

name: cas.authn.throttle.hazelcast.cluster.core.logging-type
description:
Hazelcast has a flexible logging configuration and doesn't depend on any logging framework except JDK logging. It has in-built adaptors for a number of logging frameworks and also supports custom loggers by providing logging interfaces. To use built-in adaptors you should set this setting to one of predefined types below.
  • {@code jdk}: JDK logging
  • {@code log4j}: Log4j
  • {@code slf4j}: Slf4j
  • {@code none}: Disable logging

name: cas.service-registry.cosmos-db.max-retry-attempts-on-throttled-requests
description:
Sets the maximum number of retries in the case where the request fails because the service has applied rate limiting on the client.

When a client is sending requests faster than the allowed rate, the service will return HttpStatusCode 429 (Too Many Request) to throttle the client. The current implementation in the SDK will then wait for the amount of time the service tells it to wait and retry after the time has elapsed.

The default value is 4. This means in the case where the request is throttled, the same request will be issued for a maximum of 5 times to the server before an error is returned to the application.

name: cas.events.redis.pool.max-active

name: cas.authn.gua.ldap.response-timeout

name: cas.authn.jdbc.query[].fail-fast-timeout
description:
Set the pool initialization failure timeout.
  • Any value greater than zero will be treated as a timeout for pool initialization. The calling thread will be blocked from continuing until a successful connection to the database, or until the timeout is reached. If the timeout is reached, then a {@code PoolInitializationException} will be thrown.
  • A value of zero will not prevent the pool from starting in the case that a connection cannot be obtained. However, upon start the pool will attempt to obtain a connection and validate that the {@code connectionTestQuery} and {@code connectionInitSql} are valid. If those validations fail, an exception will be thrown. If a connection cannot be obtained, the validation is skipped and the the pool will start and continue to try to obtain connections in the background. This can mean that callers to {@code DataSource#getConnection()} may encounter exceptions.
  • A value less than zero will not bypass any connection attempt and validation during startup, and therefore the pool will start immediately. The pool will continue to try to obtain connections in the background. This can mean that callers to {@code DataSource#getConnection()} may encounter exceptions.
Note that if this timeout value is greater than or equal to zero (0), and therefore an initial connection validation is performed, this timeout does not override the {@code connectionTimeout} or {@code validationTimeout}; they will be honored before this timeout is applied. The default value is one millisecond.

name: cas.webflow.session.server.hazelcast.cluster.network.network-interfaces
description:
You can specify which network interfaces that Hazelcast should use. Servers mostly have more than one network interface, so you may want to list the valid IPs. Range characters ('*' and '-') can be used for simplicity. For instance, 10.3.10.* refers to IPs between 10.3.10.0 and 10.3.10.255. Interface 10.3.10.4-18 refers to IPs between 10.3.10.4 and 10.3.10.18 (4 and 18 included). If network interface configuration is enabled (it is disabled by default) and if Hazelcast cannot find an matching interface, then it will print a message on the console and will not start on that node.

Interfaces can be separated by a comma.

name: cas.authn.pac4j.core.session-replication.cookie.max-age
description: The maximum age of the cookie, specified in seconds. By default, {@code -1} indicating the cookie will persist until browser shutdown. A positive value indicates that the cookie will expire after that many seconds have passed. Note that the value is the maximum age when the cookie will expire, not the cookie's current age. A negative value means that the cookie is not stored persistently and will be deleted when the Web browser exits. A zero value causes the cookie to be deleted.

name: cas.authn.surrogate.ldap.pool-passivator
description:
You may receive unexpected LDAP failures, when CAS is configured to authenticate using {@code DIRECT} or {@code AUTHENTICATED} types and LDAP is locked down to not allow anonymous binds/searches. Every second attempt with a given LDAP connection from the pool would fail if it was on the same connection as a failed login attempt, and the regular connection validator would similarly fail. When a connection is returned back to a pool, it still may contain the principal and credentials from the previous attempt. Before the next bind attempt using that connection, the validator tries to validate the connection again but fails because it’s no longer trying with the configured bind credentials but with whatever user DN was used in the previous step. Given the validation failure, the connection is closed and CAS would deny access by default. Passivators attempt to reconnect to LDAP with the configured bind credentials, effectively resetting the connection to what it should be after each bind request. Furthermore if you are seeing errors in the logs that resemble a 'Operation exception encountered, reopening connection' type of message, this usually is an indication that the connection pool’s validation timeout established and created by CAS is greater than the timeout configured in the LDAP server, or more likely, in the load balancer in front of the LDAP servers. You can adjust the LDAP server session’s timeout for connections, or you can teach CAS to use a validity period that is equal or less than the LDAP server session’s timeout. Accepted values are:
  • {@code NONE}: No passivation takes place.
  • {@code BIND}: The default behavior which passivates a connection by performing a bind operation on it. This option requires the availability of bind credentials when establishing connections to LDAP.

name: cas.authn.saml-idp.core.session-replication.cookie.name
description: Cookie name. Constructs a cookie with a specified name and value. The name must conform to RFC 2965. That means it can contain only ASCII alphanumeric characters and cannot contain commas, semicolons, or white space or begin with a {@code $} character. The cookie's name cannot be changed after creation. By default, cookies are created according to the RFC 2965 cookie specification. Cookie names are automatically calculated assigned by CAS at runtime, and there is usually no need to customize the name or assign it a different value unless a special use case warrants the change.

name: cas.acceptable-usage-policy.redis.port

name: cas.service-registry.jpa.pool.name
description: Set the name of the connection pool. This is primarily used for the MBean to uniquely identify the pool configuration.

name: cas.service-registry.stream.hazelcast.config.cluster.discovery.aws.connection-timeout-seconds
description: The maximum amount of time Hazelcast will try to connect to a well known member before giving up. Setting this value too low could mean that a member is not able to connect to a cluster. Setting the value too high means that member startup could slow down because of longer timeouts (for example, when a well known member is not up). Increasing this value is recommended if you have many IPs listed and the members cannot properly build up the cluster. Its default value is 5.

name: cas.authn.throttle.ldap.connection-strategy
description:
If multiple URLs are provided as the ldapURL this describes how each URL will be processed.
  • {@code ACTIVE_PASSIVE} First LDAP will be used for every request unless it fails and then the next shall be used.
  • {@code ROUND_ROBIN} For each new connection the next url in the list will be used.
  • {@code RANDOM} For each new connection a random LDAP url will be selected.
  • {@code DNS_SRV} LDAP urls based on DNS SRV records of the configured/given LDAP url will be used.

name: cas.authn.pac4j.facebook.id

name: cas.authn.surrogate.simple.search-entry-handlers[].type
description:
The type of search entry handler to choose. Available values are as follows:
  • {@code FOLLOW_SEARCH_REFERRAL}: Provides handling of an ldap referral for search operations.
  • {@code FOLLOW_SEARCH_RESULT_REFERENCE}: Provides handling of an ldap continuation reference for search operations.
  • {@code ACTIVE_DIRECTORY}: Process the entry results fetched from active directory and check for account status controls for disabled/expired accounts, etc.
  • {@code OBJECT_GUID}: Object guid search entry handler. Handles the {@code objectGUID} attribute fetching and conversion.
  • {@code OBJECT_SID}: Object sid search entry handler. Handles the {@code objectSid} attribute fetching and conversion.
  • {@code CASE_CHANGE}: Case change search entry handler. Provides the ability to modify the case of search entry DNs, attribute names, and attribute values.
  • {@code DN_ATTRIBUTE_ENTRY}: DN attribute entry handler. Adds the entry DN as an attribute to the result set. Provides a client side implementation of RFC 5020.
  • {@code MERGE}: Merge search entry handler. Merges the values of one or more attributes into a single attribute.
  • {@code PRIMARY_GROUP}: Primary group search handler. Constructs the primary group SID and then searches for that group and puts it's DN in the {@code memberOf} attribute of the original search entry.
  • {@code RANGE_ENTRY}: Range entry search handler. Rewrites attributes returned from Active Directory to include all values by performing additional searches.
  • {@code RECURSIVE_ENTRY}: Recursive entry search handler. This recursively searches based on a supplied attribute and merges those results into the original entry.
  • {@code MERGE_ENTRIES}: Merge entries handler. Merges the values of one or more attributes in all entries into a single attribute. The merged attribute may or may not already exist on the entry. If it does exist it's existing values will remain intact.

name: cas.authn.pac4j.saml[].metadata.service-provider.jdbc.fail-fast-timeout
description:
Set the pool initialization failure timeout.
  • Any value greater than zero will be treated as a timeout for pool initialization. The calling thread will be blocked from continuing until a successful connection to the database, or until the timeout is reached. If the timeout is reached, then a {@code PoolInitializationException} will be thrown.
  • A value of zero will not prevent the pool from starting in the case that a connection cannot be obtained. However, upon start the pool will attempt to obtain a connection and validate that the {@code connectionTestQuery} and {@code connectionInitSql} are valid. If those validations fail, an exception will be thrown. If a connection cannot be obtained, the validation is skipped and the the pool will start and continue to try to obtain connections in the background. This can mean that callers to {@code DataSource#getConnection()} may encounter exceptions.
  • A value less than zero will not bypass any connection attempt and validation during startup, and therefore the pool will start immediately. The pool will continue to try to obtain connections in the background. This can mean that callers to {@code DataSource#getConnection()} may encounter exceptions.
Note that if this timeout value is greater than or equal to zero (0), and therefore an initial connection validation is performed, this timeout does not override the {@code connectionTimeout} or {@code validationTimeout}; they will be honored before this timeout is applied. The default value is one millisecond.

name: cas.authn.pm.rest.endpoint-url-email

name: cas.webflow.session.server.hazelcast.cluster.discovery.kubernetes.namespace

name: cas.authn.throttle.ldap.idle-time

name: cas.webflow.session.server.hazelcast.cluster.discovery.jclouds.zones
description: Defines zone for a cloud service (optional). Can be used with comma separated values for multiple values.

name: cas.authn.attribute-repository.okta.proxy-username
description: Send requests via a proxy; define the proxy username.

name: cas.events.core.track-geolocation
description: Whether geolocation should be tracked as part of collected authentication events. This of course requires consent from the user's browser to collect stats on location. Turning on this setting would prompt the browser to ask for user's consent to collect geo location directly. If geo location information is not available using this strategy, it may still be extracted and determined based on the client IP address at the time the event is being recorded and captured by CAS.

name: cas.events.mongo.read-concern
description:
Read concern. Accepted values are:
  • {@code LOCAL}
  • {@code MAJORITY}
  • {@code LINEARIZABLE}
  • {@code SNAPSHOT}
  • {@code AVAILABLE}

name: cas.authn.passwordless.accounts.ldap.base-dn
description: Base DN to use. There may be scenarios where different parts of a single LDAP tree could be considered as base-dns. Rather than duplicating the LDAP configuration block for each individual base-dn, each entry can be specified and joined together using a special delimiter character. The user DN is retrieved using the combination of all base-dn and DN resolvers in the order defined. DN resolution should fail if multiple DNs are found. Otherwise the first DN found is returned. Usual syntax is: {@code subtreeA,dc=example,dc=net|subtreeC,dc=example,dc=net}.

name: cas.ticket.registry.ignite.trust-store-type
description: Truststore type used to create a SSL context for the ticket registry.

name: cas.authn.oidc.jwks.rotation.schedule.repeat-interval
description: String representation of a repeat interval of re-loading data for a data store implementation. This is the timeout between consecutive job’s executions.

name: cas.ticket.registry.hazelcast.cluster.network.public-address
description: The default public address to be advertised to other cluster members and clients.

name: cas.authn.throttle.ldap.trust-store-password
description: Password needed to open the truststore.

name: cas.acceptable-usage-policy.jdbc.leak-threshold
description: Controls the amount of time that a connection can be out of the pool before a message is logged indicating a possible connection leak.

name: cas.authn.mfa.simple.token.bypass.rest.headers
description: Headers, defined as a Map, to include in the request when making the REST call. Will overwrite any header that CAS is pre-defined to send and include in the request. Key in the map should be the header name and the value in the map should be the header value.

name: cas.authn.mfa.web-authn.ldap.pool-passivator
description:
You may receive unexpected LDAP failures, when CAS is configured to authenticate using {@code DIRECT} or {@code AUTHENTICATED} types and LDAP is locked down to not allow anonymous binds/searches. Every second attempt with a given LDAP connection from the pool would fail if it was on the same connection as a failed login attempt, and the regular connection validator would similarly fail. When a connection is returned back to a pool, it still may contain the principal and credentials from the previous attempt. Before the next bind attempt using that connection, the validator tries to validate the connection again but fails because it’s no longer trying with the configured bind credentials but with whatever user DN was used in the previous step. Given the validation failure, the connection is closed and CAS would deny access by default. Passivators attempt to reconnect to LDAP with the configured bind credentials, effectively resetting the connection to what it should be after each bind request. Furthermore if you are seeing errors in the logs that resemble a 'Operation exception encountered, reopening connection' type of message, this usually is an indication that the connection pool’s validation timeout established and created by CAS is greater than the timeout configured in the LDAP server, or more likely, in the load balancer in front of the LDAP servers. You can adjust the LDAP server session’s timeout for connections, or you can teach CAS to use a validity period that is equal or less than the LDAP server session’s timeout. Accepted values are:
  • {@code NONE}: No passivation takes place.
  • {@code BIND}: The default behavior which passivates a connection by performing a bind operation on it. This option requires the availability of bind credentials when establishing connections to LDAP.

name: cas.monitor.endpoints.ldap.search-filter
description:
User filter to use for searching. Syntax is {@code cn={user}} or {@code cn={0}}.

You may also provide an external groovy script in the syntax of {@code file:/path/to/GroovyScript.groovy} to fully build the final filter template dynamically.

name: cas.consent.mongo.port
description: MongoDb database port.

name: cas.authn.reject.principal-transformation.blocking-pattern
description: A regular expression that will be used against the username to match for blocking/forbidden values. If a match is found, an exception will be thrown and principal transformation will fail.

name: cas.acceptable-usage-policy.jdbc.aup-column
description: The column to store the AUP attribute. May differ from the profile attribute defined by {@link AcceptableUsagePolicyCoreProperties#getAupAttributeName()}. SQL query can be further customized by setting {@link #sqlUpdate}.

name: cas.authn.pac4j.foursquare.callback-url-type
description:
Determine how the callback url should be resolved. Default is {@link CallbackUrlTypes#QUERY_PARAMETER}. Available values are as follows:
  • {@code PATH_PARAMETER}: Path parameter callback url. The client name is added to the path of the callback URL.
  • {@code QUERY_PARAMETER}: Query parameter callback url. The client name is added to the path of a query parameter.
  • {@code NONE}: No callback url. No name is added to the callback URL to be able to distinguish the client.

name: cas.acceptable-usage-policy.ldap[].min-pool-size
description:
Minimum LDAP connection pool size.
Size the pool should be initialized to and pruned to

name: cas.authn.oidc.jwks.jpa.default-schema
description: Qualify unqualified table names with the given schema/tablespace in generated SQL.

name: cas.authn.pac4j.yahoo.callback-url
description: Callback URL to use to return the flow back to the CAS server one the identity provider is successfully done. This may be used at the discretion of the client and its type to build service parameters, redirect URIs, etc. If none is specified, the CAS server's login endpoint will be used as the basis of the final callback url.

name: cas.service-registry.stream.core.replication-mode
description:
Indicates the replication mod. Available values are as follows:
  • {@code ACTIVE}: In this replication mode, all CAS nodes will try to sync copies of service definition files individually on each node.
  • {@code PASSIVE}: In this replication mode, one CAS service is designated to be the master that contains all service definition files locally, and will stream changes to other CAS passive nodes. Passive CAS nodes only access the replication cache to retrieve services, and will not individually keep copies of the service definition files on disk.

name: cas.authn.gua.ldap.max-pool-size
description: Maximum LDAP connection pool size which the pool can use to grow.

name: cas.authn.saml-idp.metadata.rest.crypto.alg
description: The signing/encryption algorithm to use.

name: cas.sms-provider.text-magic.debugging
description: Check that whether debugging is enabled for this API client.

name: cas.locale.cookie.secure
description: True if sending this cookie should be restricted to a secure protocol, or false if the it can be sent using any protocol.

name: cas.authn.pm.google-recaptcha.verify-url
description: The google reCAPTCHA endpoint for verification of tokens and input.

name: cas.service-registry.redis.pool.max-wait
description: Maximum amount of time (in milliseconds) a connection allocation should block before throwing an exception when the pool is exhausted. Use a negative value to block indefinitely.

name: cas.authn.surrogate.simple.disable-pooling
description: Whether to use a pooled connection factory in components.

name: cas.authn.pac4j.paypal.id
description: The client id.

name: cas.authn.x509.serial-no-dn.serial-number-prefix
description: The serial number prefix used for principal resolution when type is set to {@link X509Properties.PrincipalTypes#SERIAL_NO_DN}.

name: cas.authn.redis.name
description: The name of the authentication handler.

name: cas.authn.mfa.yubikey.bypass.authentication-method-name
description: Skip multifactor authentication depending on method/form of primary authentication execution. Specifically, skip multifactor if the authentication method attribute collected as part of authentication metadata matches a certain value.

name: cas.service-registry.dynamo-db.billing-mode
description:
Billing mode specifies how you are charged for read and write throughput and how you manage capacity. Available values are as follows:
  • {@code PROVISIONED}: Provisioned mode means that you specify the number of reads and writes per second that you expect your application to use. Provisioned mode is a good option if any of the following are true:
    • You have predictable application traffic.
    • You run applications whose traffic is consistent or ramps gradually.
    • You can forecast capacity requirements to control costs.
    You can use auto scaling to automatically adjust capacity based on the specified utilization rate to ensure application performance while reducing costs.
  • {@code PAY_PER_REQUEST}: Pay-per-request or on-demand billing means that you're charged for only the read/write requests that you use. On-demand mode is a good option if any of the following are true:
    • You create new tables with unknown workloads.
    • You have unpredictable application traffic.
    • You prefer the ease of paying for only what you use.
    Tables using on-demand mode support all DynamoDB features (such as encryption at rest, point-in-time recovery, global tables, and so on) with the exception of auto scaling, which is not applicable with this mode.

name: cas.authn.passwordless.accounts.ldap.search-entry-handlers[].dn-attribute.add-if-exists
description: The Add if exists.

name: cas.authn.pac4j.cas[].display-name
description:
Indicate the title or display name of the client
for decoration and client presentation purposes.
If left blank, the client original name would be used by default.

name: cas.authn.pac4j.yahoo.secret

name: cas.authn.surrogate.ldap.member-attribute-name

name: cas.saml-sp.sserca.description

name: cas.saml-sp.crash-plan.metadata

name: cas.authn.mfa.authy.mail-attribute

name: cas.saml-sp.cher-well.name
description: Name of this service provider.

name: cas.authn.radius.server.nas-real-port

name: cas.google-recaptcha.enabled
description: Whether google reCAPTCHA should be enabled.

name: cas.authn.jaas[].password-policy.login-failures
description: When dealing with FreeIPA, indicates the number of allows login failures.

name: cas.consent.jpa.isolation-level-name
description: Defines the isolation level for transactions. @see org.springframework.transaction.TransactionDefinition

name: cas.tgc.secure
description: True if sending this cookie should be restricted to a secure protocol, or false if the it can be sent using any protocol.

name: cas.consent.core.crypto.signing.key-size
description: The signing key size.

name: cas.authn.pac4j.profile-selection.groovy.location
description:
The location of the resource. Resources can be URLs, or files found either on the classpath or outside somewhere in the file system.

In the event the configured resource is a Groovy script, specially if the script set to reload on changes, you may need to adjust the total number of {@code inotify} instances. On Linux, you may need to add the following line to {@code /etc/sysctl.conf}: {@code fs.inotify.max_user_instances = 256}.

You can check the current value via {@code cat /proc/sys/fs/inotify/max_user_instances}.

name: cas.authn.surrogate.principal.principal-transformation.prefix
description: Prefix to add to the principal id prior to authentication.

name: cas.authn.wsfed[].attribute-mutator-script.location
description:
Path to attribute mutator groovy script that allows one to modify wsfed attributes before establishing a final principal. The location of the resource. Resources can be URLs, or files found either on the classpath or outside somewhere in the file system.

In the event the configured resource is a Groovy script, specially if the script set to reload on changes, you may need to adjust the total number of {@code inotify} instances. On Linux, you may need to add the following line to {@code /etc/sysctl.conf}: {@code fs.inotify.max_user_instances = 256}.

You can check the current value via {@code cat /proc/sys/fs/inotify/max_user_instances}.

name: cas.service-registry.dynamo-db.proxy-password
description: Optionally specifies the proxy password to connect through.

name: cas.google-firebase-messaging.service-account-key

name: cas.monitor.ldap
description: Options for monitoring LDAP resources.

name: cas.authn.jdbc.search[].principal-transformation.blocking-pattern
description:
A regular expression that will be used against the username
to match for blocking/forbidden values.
If a match is found, an exception will be thrown
and principal transformation will fail.

name: cas.ticket.registry.jpa.data-source-name
description: Attempts to do a JNDI data source look up for the data source name specified. Will attempt to locate the data source object as is.

name: cas.authn.x509.serial-no.principal-s-n-radix

name: cas.consent.redis.cluster.max-redirects

name: cas.saml-sp.gitlab.name

name: cas.locale.cookie.path
description: Cookie path. Specifies a path for the cookie to which the client should return the cookie. The cookie is visible to all the pages in the directory you specify, and all the pages in that directory's subdirectories. A cookie's path must include the servlet that set the cookie, for example, /catalog, which makes the cookie visible to all directories on the server under /catalog. Consult RFC 2965 (available on the Internet) for more information on setting path names for cookies.

name: cas.authn.mfa.trusted.jpa.driver-class
description: The JDBC driver used to connect to the database.

name: cas.ticket.registry.hazelcast.crypto.encryption.key
description: The encryption key. The encryption key by default and unless specified otherwise must be randomly-generated string whose length is defined by the encryption key size setting.

name: cas.authn.pac4j.saml[].metadata.service-provider.mongo.password
description: MongoDb database password for authentication.

name: cas.service-registry.stream.hazelcast.config.cluster.discovery.docker-swarm.dns-provider.enabled
description: Enable provider.

name: cas.acceptable-usage-policy.redis.cluster.nodes[].type
description:
Indicate the type/role of this node.
Accepted values are: {@code MASTER, REPLICA}.

name: cas.authn.throttle.jdbc.driver-class
description: The JDBC driver used to connect to the database.

name: cas.authn.mongo.order
description: Order of authentication handler in chain.

name: cas.consent.redis.cluster.topology-refresh-period
description: Enables periodic refresh of cluster topology and sets the refresh period.

name: cas.authn.passwordless.accounts.ldap.subtree-search
description: Whether subtree searching is allowed.

name: cas.authn.pm.jdbc.isolation-level-name
description: Defines the isolation level for transactions. @see org.springframework.transaction.TransactionDefinition

name: cas.authn.mfa.simple.mail.bcc
description: Email BCC address, if any.

name: cas.google-analytics.cookie.domain
description: Cookie domain. Specifies the domain within which this cookie should be presented. The form of the domain name is specified by RFC 2965. A domain name begins with a dot (.foo.com) and means that the cookie is visible to servers in a specified Domain Name System (DNS) zone (for example, www.foo.com, but not a.b.foo.com). By default, cookies are only returned to the server that sent them.

name: cas.authn.jdbc.encode[].idle-timeout
description: Controls the maximum amount of time that a connection is allowed to sit idle in the pool.

name: cas.authn.attribute-repository.redis[].password
description: Login password of the redis server.

name: cas.authn.mfa.web-authn.bypass.rest.basic-auth-password
description: If REST endpoint is protected via basic authentication, specify the password for authentication.

name: cas.authn.pac4j.profile-selection.ldap.sasl-quality-of-protection
description: SASL quality of protected.

name: cas.service-registry.stream.hazelcast.config.cluster.core.eviction-policy
description: Hazelcast supports policy-based eviction for distributed maps. Currently supported policies are LRU (Least Recently Used) and LFU (Least Frequently Used) and NONE. See this for more info.

name: cas.authn.mfa.yubikey.mongo.drop-collection
description: Whether collections should be dropped on startup and re-created.

name: cas.authn.pm.jdbc.password-encoder.encoding-algorithm
description: The encoding algorithm to use such as {@code MD5}. Relevant when the type used is {@code DEFAULT} or {@code GLIBC_CRYPT}. When used with {@link PasswordEncoderTypes#PBKDF2}, it should be one of {@code PBKDF2WithHmacSHA1}, {@code PBKDF2WithHmacSHA256} or {@code PBKDF2WithHmacSHA512}.

name: cas.ticket.registry.hazelcast.cluster.discovery.kubernetes.kubernetes-master
description: Defines an alternative address for the kubernetes master. Defaults to: {@code https://kubernetes.default.svc}

name: cas.authn.jdbc.search[].field-password
description: Password column name.

name: cas.authn.mfa.web-authn.redis.cluster.dynamic-refresh-sources
description: Whether to discover and query all cluster nodes for obtaining the cluster topology. When set to false, only the initial seed nodes are used as sources for topology discovery.

name: cas.authn.mfa.yubikey.mongo.client-uri
description: The connection uri to the mongodb instance. This typically takes on the form of {@code mongodb://user:psw@ds135522.somewhere.com:35522/db}. If not specified, will fallback onto other individual settings. If specified, takes over all other settings where applicable.

name: cas.saml-sp.box.sign-assertions
description: Indicate whether assertions should be signed.

name: cas.authn.passwordless.accounts.ldap.connect-timeout
description: Sets the maximum amount of time that connects will block.

name: cas.saml-sp.docu-sign.sign-responses
description: Indicate whether responses should be signed.

name: cas.authn.jdbc.bind[].isolation-level-name
description: Defines the isolation level for transactions.

name: cas.authn.mfa.inwebo.bypass.principal-attribute-name
description: Skip multifactor authentication based on designated principal attribute names.

name: cas.authn.mfa.gauth.ldap.search-entry-handlers[].recursive.search-attribute
description: The Search attribute.

name: cas.authn.mfa.radius.client.accounting-port
description: The accounting port.

name: cas.authn.okta.principal-transformation.suffix
description: Suffix to add to the principal id prior to authentication.

name: cas.authn.mfa.simple.bypass.http-request-headers
description: Skip multifactor authentication if the http request contains the defined header names. Header names may be comma-separated and can be regular expressions; values are ignored.

name: cas.authn.mfa.gauth.jpa.isolation-level-name
description: Defines the isolation level for transactions. @see org.springframework.transaction.TransactionDefinition

name: cas.authn.throttle.jdbc.enabled
description: Decide whether JDBC audits should be enabled.

name: cas.saml-sp.open-athens.signature-location
description: Signature location used to verify metadata.

name: cas.authn.passwordless.accounts.ldap.search-entry-handlers[].search-referral.limit
description: The default referral limit.

name: cas.authn.passwordless.accounts.ldap.validator.type
description:
Determine the LDAP validator type.

The following LDAP validators can be used to test connection health status:

  • {@code search}: Validates a connection is healthy by performing a search operation. Validation is considered successful if the search result size is greater than zero.
  • {@code none}: No validation takes place.
  • {@code compare}: Validates a connection is healthy by performing a compare operation.

name: cas.authn.pac4j.saml[].certificate-expiration-days
description:
Define the validity period for the certificate
in number of days. The end-date of the certificate
is controlled by this setting, when defined as a value
greater than zero.

name: cas.server.tomcat.clustering.membership-local-loopback-disabled
description: Membership uses multicast, it will call java.net.MulticastSocket.setLoopbackMode(localLoopbackDisabled). When localLoopbackDisabled==true multicast messages will not reach other nodes on the same local machine. The default is false.

name: cas.saml-sp.sserca.name-id-attribute
description: Attribute to use when generating nameids for this SP.

name: cas.acceptable-usage-policy.jdbc.url
description: The database connection URL.

name: cas.authn.oidc.jwks.jpa.pool.suspension
description:
Whether or not pool suspension is allowed.

There is a performance impact when pool suspension is enabled. Unless you need it (for a redundancy system for example) do not enable it.

name: cas.authn.throttle.ldap.trust-manager
description:
Trust Manager options. Trust managers are responsible for managing the trust material that is used when making LDAP trust decisions, and for deciding whether credentials presented by a peer should be accepted. Accepted values are: *
  • {@code DEFAULT}: Enable and force the default JVM trust managers.
  • {@code ANY}: Trust any client or server.

name: cas.authn.wsfed-idp.sts.conditions-accept-client-lifetime
description: Set whether client lifetime is accepted.

name: cas.google-recaptcha.activate-for-ip-address-pattern
description: A regular expression pattern to indicate that captcha should be activated when the remote IP address matches this pattern, and otherwise skipped and disabled.

name: cas.ticket.registry.cassandra.local-dc
description: Used by a DC-ware round-robin load balancing policy. This policy provides round-robin queries over the node of the local data center. It also includes in the query plans returned a configurable number of hosts in the remote data centers, but those are always tried after the local nodes. In other words, this policy guarantees that no host in a remote data center will be queried unless no host in the local data center can be reached.

name: cas.monitor.mongo[].socket-keep-alive
description: Whether the database socket connection should be tagged with keep-alive.

name: cas.saml-sp.cranium-cafe.entity-ids
description: List of entityIds allowed for this service provider. Multiple ids can be specified in the event that the metadata is an aggregate.

name: cas.authn.saml-idp.metadata.redis.protocol-version
description: Redis protocol version.

name: cas.consent.jpa.password
description: The database connection password.

name: cas.authn.mfa.simple.bypass.credential-class-type
description: Skip multifactor authentication depending on form of primary credentials. Value must equal the fully qualified class name of the credential type.

name: cas.sms-provider.text-magic.api-key-prefix
description: set API key prefix for the first API key authentication.

name: cas.authn.gua.ldap.search-entry-handlers[].search-referral.limit
description: The default referral limit.

name: cas.authn.x509.principal.principal-resolution-failure-fatal
description: When true, throws an error back indicating that principal resolution has failed and no principal can be found based on the authentication requirements. Otherwise, logs the condition as an error without raising a catastrophic error.

name: cas.acceptable-usage-policy.ldap[].idle-time
description:
Removes connections from the pool based on how long they have been idle in the available queue.
Prunes connections that have been idle for more than the indicated amount.

name: cas.authn.syncope.provisioning.domain
description: Syncope domain used for authentication, etc. Multiple domains can be separated via comma. Each domain entry results in a separate authentication attempt and transaction by CAS.

name: cas.authn.spnego.ldap.trust-certificates
description: Path of the trust certificates to use for the SSL connection. Ignores keystore-related settings when activated and used.

name: cas.ticket.registry.redis.cluster.nodes[].type
description:
Indicate the type/role of this node.
Accepted values are: {@code MASTER, REPLICA}.

name: cas.scim.oauth-token
description: Authenticate into the SCIM server/service via a pre-generated OAuth token.

name: cas.service-registry.ldap.block-wait-time
description: The length of time the pool will block. By default the pool will block indefinitely and there is no guarantee that waiting threads will be serviced in the order in which they made their request. This option should be used with a blocking connection pool when you need to control the exact number of connections that can be created

name: cas.authn.pac4j.saml[].message-store-factory
description:
Factory implementing this interface provides services for storing and retrieval of SAML messages for e.g. verification of retrieved responses. The default factory is an always empty store. You may choose {@code org.pac4j.saml.store.HttpSessionStore} instead which allows SAML messages to be stored in a distributed session store specially required for high availability deployments and validation operations.

Available options are:

  • {@code EMPTY}: Uses the {@code EmptyStoreFactory}
  • {@code SESSION}: Uses the {@code HttpSessionStore}
  • Fully-qualified class name of the message store implementation.

Also note that the message store implementation can be supplied and configured at runtime as a Spring {@code @Bean} with the type {@code SAMLMessageStoreFactory} which, if found in the available application context, will override all other options.

name: cas.authn.mfa.yubikey.jpa.ddl-auto
description:
Hibernate feature to automatically validate and exports DDL to the schema. By default, creates and drops the schema automatically when a session is starts and ends. Setting the value to {@code validate} or {@code none} may be more desirable for production, but any of the following options can be used:
  • {@code validate}: Validate the schema, but make no changes to the database.
  • {@code update}: Update the schema.
  • {@code create}: Create the schema, destroying previous data.
  • {@code create-drop}: Drop the schema at the end of the session.
  • {@code none}: Do nothing.

Note that during a version migration where any schema has changed {@code create-drop} will result in the loss of all data as soon as CAS is started. For transient data like tickets this is probably not an issue, but in cases like the audit table important data could be lost. Using `update`, while safe for data, is confirmed to result in invalid database state. {@code validate} or {@code none} settings are likely the only safe options for production use.

For more info, see this.

name: cas.sso.create-sso-cookie-on-renew-authn
description: Flag that indicates whether to create SSO session on re-newed authentication event.

name: cas.authn.mfa.gauth.ldap.trust-certificates
description: Path of the trust certificates to use for the SSL connection. Ignores keystore-related settings when activated and used.

name: cas.authn.saml-idp.metadata.redis.sentinel.node
description: list of host:port pairs.

name: cas.authn.ldap[].keystore
description:
Path to the keystore used for SSL connections.
Typically contains SSL certificates for the LDAP server.

name: cas.interrupt.rest.headers
description: Headers, defined as a Map, to include in the request when making the REST call. Will overwrite any header that CAS is pre-defined to send and include in the request. Key in the map should be the header name and the value in the map should be the header value.

name: cas.account-registration.provisioning.syncope.realm
description: Syncope realm used for user provisioning. Realms define a hierarchical security domain tree, primarily meant for containing users. The root realm contains everything, and other realms can be seen as containers that split up the total number of entities into smaller pools.

name: cas.server.tomcat.csrf.enabled
description: Enable filter.

name: cas.authn.password-sync.ldap[].sasl-mutual-auth
description: SASL mutual auth is enabled?

name: cas.authn.surrogate.principal.principal-resolution-conflict-strategy
description: In the event that the principal resolution engine resolves more than one principal, (specially if such principals in the chain have different identifiers), this setting determines strategy by which the principal id would be chosen from the chain. Accepted values are: {@code last}, {@code first}.

name: cas.authn.mfa.web-authn.bypass.principal-attribute-value
description: Optionally, skip multifactor authentication based on designated principal attribute values.

name: cas.authn.throttle.jdbc.ddl-auto
description:
Hibernate feature to automatically validate and exports DDL to the schema. By default, creates and drops the schema automatically when a session is starts and ends. Setting the value to {@code validate} or {@code none} may be more desirable for production, but any of the following options can be used:
  • {@code validate}: Validate the schema, but make no changes to the database.
  • {@code update}: Update the schema.
  • {@code create}: Create the schema, destroying previous data.
  • {@code create-drop}: Drop the schema at the end of the session.
  • {@code none}: Do nothing.

Note that during a version migration where any schema has changed {@code create-drop} will result in the loss of all data as soon as CAS is started. For transient data like tickets this is probably not an issue, but in cases like the audit table important data could be lost. Using `update`, while safe for data, is confirmed to result in invalid database state. {@code validate} or {@code none} settings are likely the only safe options for production use.

For more info, see this.

name: cas.authn.mfa.yubikey.jpa.fail-fast-timeout
description:
Set the pool initialization failure timeout.
  • Any value greater than zero will be treated as a timeout for pool initialization. The calling thread will be blocked from continuing until a successful connection to the database, or until the timeout is reached. If the timeout is reached, then a {@code PoolInitializationException} will be thrown.
  • A value of zero will not prevent the pool from starting in the case that a connection cannot be obtained. However, upon start the pool will attempt to obtain a connection and validate that the {@code connectionTestQuery} and {@code connectionInitSql} are valid. If those validations fail, an exception will be thrown. If a connection cannot be obtained, the validation is skipped and the the pool will start and continue to try to obtain connections in the background. This can mean that callers to {@code DataSource#getConnection()} may encounter exceptions.
  • A value less than zero will not bypass any connection attempt and validation during startup, and therefore the pool will start immediately. The pool will continue to try to obtain connections in the background. This can mean that callers to {@code DataSource#getConnection()} may encounter exceptions.
Note that if this timeout value is greater than or equal to zero (0), and therefore an initial connection validation is performed, this timeout does not override the {@code connectionTimeout} or {@code validationTimeout}; they will be honored before this timeout is applied. The default value is one millisecond.

It additionally accepts 'uncompressed' which is equivalent to no compression; and 'producer' which means retain the original compression codec set by the producer.

Azure AD tenant name can take 4 different values:

  • {@code organizations}: Only users with work or school accounts from Azure AD can sign in.
  • {@code consumers}: Only users with a personal Microsoft account can sign in.

description: Base DN to use. There may be scenarios where different parts of a single LDAP tree could be considered as base-dns. Rather than duplicating the LDAP configuration block for each individual base-dn, each entry can be specified and joined together using a special delimiter character. The user DN is retrieved using the combination of all base-dn and DN resolvers in the order defined. DN resolution should fail if multiple DNs are found. Otherwise the first DN found is returned. name: cas.authn.mfa.trusted.device-fingerprint.cookie.same-site-policy
description:
If a cookie is only intended to be accessed in a first party context, the developer has the option to apply one of settings {@code SameSite=Lax} or {@code SameSite=Strict} or {@code SameSite=None} to prevent external access.

To safeguard more websites and their users, the new secure-by-default model assumes all cookies should be protected from external access unless otherwise specified. Developers must use a new cookie setting, {@code SameSite=None}, to designate cookies for cross-site access. When the {@code SameSite=None} attribute is present, an additional {@code Secure} attribute is used so cross-site cookies can only be accessed over HTTPS connections.

Accepted values are:
  • {@code Lax}
  • {@code Strict}
  • {@code None}
  • {@code Off}: Disable the generation of the SameSite cookie attribute altogether.
  • Path to a Groovy script that is able to generate the SameSite cookie attribute dynamically.
  • Fully qualified name of a class that implements {@code org.apereo.cas.web.cookie.CookieSameSitePolicy}

name: cas.authn.attribute-repository.jdbc[].physical-naming-strategy-class-name

The location of the resource. Resources can be URLs, or files found either on the classpath or outside somewhere in the file system.

In the event the configured resource is a Groovy script, specially if the script set to reload on changes, you may need to adjust the total number of {@code inotify} instances. On Linux, you may need to add the following line to {@code /etc/sysctl.conf}: {@code fs.inotify.max_user_instances = 256}.

You can check the current value via {@code cat /proc/sys/fs/inotify/max_user_instances}.

name: cas.authn.mfa.gauth.jpa.dialect
description: The database dialect is a configuration setting for platform independent software (JPA, Hibernate, etc) which allows such software to translate its generic SQL statements into vendor specific DDL, DML.

description: Controls the maximum amount of time that a connection is allowed to sit idle in the pool.

name: cas.server.tomcat.ajp.secret
description: Set the secret that must be included with every request.

name: cas.ticket.registry.mongo.replica-set
description: A replica set in MongoDB is a group of {@code mongod} processes that maintain the same data set. Replica sets provide redundancy and high availability, and are the basis for all production deployments.

name: cas.sms-provider.sns.credential-secret-key
description: Use secret key provided by AWS to authenticate.

name: cas.consent.redis.connect-timeout

name: cas.interrupt.cookie.path
description: Cookie path. Specifies a path for the cookie to which the client should return the cookie. The cookie is visible to all the pages in the directory you specify, and all the pages in that directory's subdirectories. A cookie's path must include the servlet that set the cookie, for example, /catalog, which makes the cookie visible to all directories on the server under /catalog. Consult RFC 2965 (available on the Internet) for more information on setting path names for cookies.

name: cas.authn.throttle.ldap.account-locked-attribute
description: Name of LDAP attribute that represents the account locked status. The value of the attribute is set to {@code "true"} if the account is ever updated to indicated a locked status.

name: cas.monitor.ldap[].pool.min-size
description:
Controls the minimum size that the pool is allowed
to reach, including both idle and in-use connections.

name: cas.authn.x509.subject-dn.format
description:
Format of subject DN to use. Available values are as follows:
  • {@code DEFAULT}: Denigrated result of calling certificate.getSubjectDN() method. Javadocs designate this method as "denigrated" for not being portable and/or not being well defined. It is what has been used by CAS for a long time so it remains the default.
  • {@code RFC1779}: RFC 1779 String format of Distinguished Names. Calls {@code X500Principal.getName("RFC1779")} which emits a subject DN with the attribute keywords defined in RFC 1779 (CN, L, ST, O, OU, C, STREET). Any other attribute type is emitted as an OID.
  • {@code RFC2253}: RFC 2253 String format of Distinguished Names. Calls {@code X500Principal.getName("RFC2253")} which emits a subject DN with the attribute keywords defined in RFC 2253 (CN, L, ST, O, OU, C, STREET, DC, UID). Any other attribute type is emitted as an OID.
  • {@code CANONICAL}: Canonical String format of Distinguished Names. Calls X500Principal.getName("CANONICAL" which emits a subject DN that starts with RFC 2253 and applies additional canonicalizations described in the javadoc.

name: cas.monitor.endpoints.ldap.sasl-quality-of-protection
description: SASL quality of protected.

name: cas.webflow.session.server.hazelcast.cluster.discovery.aws.tag-key
description: If a tag key/value is set, only instances with that tag key/value will be selected.

name: cas.authn.mfa.yubikey.failure-mode
description:
The failure mode policy for this MFA provider. The authentication policy by default supports fail-closed mode, which means that if you attempt to exercise a particular provider available to CAS and the provider cannot be reached, authentication will be stopped and an error will be displayed. You can of course change this behavior so that authentication proceeds without exercising the provider functionality, if that provider cannot respond. Each defined multifactor authentication provider can set its own failure mode policy. Failure modes set at this location will override the global failure mode, but defer to any failure mode set by the registered service. Available values are as follows:
  • {@code OPEN}: Disallow MFA, proceed with authentication but don't communicate MFA to the RP.
  • {@code CLOSED}: Disallow MFA, block with authentication.
  • {@code PHANTOM}: Disallow MFA, proceed with authentication and communicate MFA to the RP.
  • {@code NONE}: Do not check for failure at all.
  • {@code UNDEFINED}: The default one indicating that no failure mode is set at all.

name: cas.authn.oidc.registration.dynamic-client-registration-mode

Whether dynamic registration operates in {@code OPEN} or {@code PROTECTED} mode. Available values are as follows:
  • {@code OPEN}: Registration is open to all. In a situation where CAS is supporting open Client registration, it will check to see if the {@code logo_uri} and {@code policy_uri} have the same host as the hosts defined in the array of {@code redirect_uris}.
  • {@code PROTECTED}: registration is protected for all.

Maximum amount of time (in milliseconds) a connection allocation should block

name: cas.authn.oauth.uma.resource-set.jpa.idle-timeout

name: cas.authn.attribute-repository.jdbc[].fetch-size

name: cas.service-registry.cosmos-db.indexing-mode
description:
Specifies the supported indexing modes in the Azure Cosmos DB database service. Accepted values are:
  • {@code CONSISTENT}: Index is updated synchronously with a create or update operation. With consistent indexing, query behavior is the same as the default consistency level for the collection. The index is always kept up to date with the data.
  • {@code LAZY}: Index is updated asynchronously with respect to a create or update operation. With lazy indexing, queries are eventually consistent. The index is updated when the collection is idle.
  • {@code NONE}: No index is provided. Setting IndexingMode to "None" drops the index. Use this if you don't want to maintain the index for a document collection, to save the storage cost or improve the write throughput. Your queries will degenerate to scans of the entire collection.

name: cas.authn.throttle.hazelcast.cluster.wan-replication.targets[].snapshot-enabled
description: When set to true, only the latest events (based on key) are selected and sent in a batch.

name: cas.authn.mfa.web-authn.mongo.write-concern
description: Write concern describes the level of acknowledgement requested from MongoDB for write operations to a standalone mongo db or to replica sets or to sharded clusters. In sharded clusters, mongo db instances will pass the write concern on to the shards.

name: cas.authn.saml-idp.services.defaults
description: Control the default, initial values for fields that are part of a SAML service definition. This is defined as a map where the key is the field name (i.e. {@code signAssertions}) and the value should be the default value. If a service definition explicitly defines a value for a field, that value will take over and the default defined here will be ignored. If a service definition does not define a value for a field and no defaults are specified for that field, then the default value that is directly assigned to the field in the body of the service definition will take over.

name: cas.service-registry.cassandra.keyspace
description: Keyspace address to use where the cluster would connect.

name: cas.ticket.registry.cosmos-db.max-retry-attempts-on-throttled-requests
description:
Sets the maximum number of retries in the case where the request fails because the service has applied rate limiting on the client.

When a client is sending requests faster than the allowed rate, the service will return HttpStatusCode 429 (Too Many Request) to throttle the client. The current implementation in the SDK will then wait for the amount of time the service tells it to wait and retry after the time has elapsed.

The default value is 4. This means in the case where the request is throttled, the same request will be issued for a maximum of 5 times to the server before an error is returned to the application.

name: cas.authn.mfa.radius.bypass.rest.method
description: HTTP method to use when contacting the rest endpoint. Examples include {@code GET, POST}, etc.

name: cas.ticket.registry.redis.pool.test-while-idle
description: Returns whether objects sitting idle in the pool will be validated by the idle object evictor ( if any - see setTimeBetweenEvictionRunsMillis(long)). Validation is performed by the validateObject() method of the factory associated with the pool. If the object fails to validate, it will be removed from the pool and destroyed.

name: cas.saml-sp.gitlab.name-id-format

Define the scope and state of this authentication handler and the lifecycle in which it can be invoked or activated. Available values are as follows:

name: cas.consent.ldap.pool-passivator
description:
You may receive unexpected LDAP failures, when CAS is configured to authenticate using {@code DIRECT} or {@code AUTHENTICATED} types and LDAP is locked down to not allow anonymous binds/searches. Every second attempt with a given LDAP connection from the pool would fail if it was on the same connection as a failed login attempt, and the regular connection validator would similarly fail. When a connection is returned back to a pool, it still may contain the principal and credentials from the previous attempt. Before the next bind attempt using that connection, the validator tries to validate the connection again but fails because it’s no longer trying with the configured bind credentials but with whatever user DN was used in the previous step. Given the validation failure, the connection is closed and CAS would deny access by default. Passivators attempt to reconnect to LDAP with the configured bind credentials, effectively resetting the connection to what it should be after each bind request. Furthermore if you are seeing errors in the logs that resemble a 'Operation exception encountered, reopening connection' type of message, this usually is an indication that the connection pool’s validation timeout established and created by CAS is greater than the timeout configured in the LDAP server, or more likely, in the load balancer in front of the LDAP servers. You can adjust the LDAP server session’s timeout for connections, or you can teach CAS to use a validity period that is equal or less than the LDAP server session’s timeout. Accepted values are:
  • {@code NONE}: No passivation takes place.
  • {@code BIND}: The default behavior which passivates a connection by performing a bind operation on it. This option requires the availability of bind credentials when establishing connections to LDAP.

name: cas.google-apps.key-algorithm
description: Signature algorithm used to generate keys. @deprecated Since 6.2

name: cas.authn.mfa.u2f.groovy.location
description:
The location of the resource. Resources can be URLs, or files found either on the classpath or outside somewhere in the file system.

In the event the configured resource is a Groovy script, specially if the script set to reload on changes, you may need to adjust the total number of {@code inotify} instances. On Linux, you may need to add the following line to {@code /etc/sysctl.conf}: {@code fs.inotify.max_user_instances = 256}.

You can check the current value via {@code cat /proc/sys/fs/inotify/max_user_instances}.

name: cas.monitor.endpoints.ldap.block-wait-time
description: The length of time the pool will block. By default the pool will block indefinitely and there is no guarantee that waiting threads will be serviced in the order in which they made their request. This option should be used with a blocking connection pool when you need to control the exact number of connections that can be created

name: cas.authn.oauth.csrf-cookie.path

The cookie is visible to all the pages in the directory you specify, and all the pages in that directory's subdirectories. A cookie's path must include the servlet that set the cookie, for example, /catalog, which makes the cookie visible to all directories on the server under /catalog. Consult RFC 2965 (available on the Internet) for more information on setting path names for cookies.

This property determines whether data source isolates internal pool queries, such as the connection alive test, in their own transaction.

name: cas.locale.cookie.max-age
description: The maximum age of the cookie, specified in seconds. By default, {@code -1} indicating the cookie will persist until browser shutdown. A positive value indicates that the cookie will expire after that many seconds have passed. Note that the value is the maximum age when the cookie will expire, not the cookie's current age. A negative value means that the cookie is not stored persistently and will be deleted when the Web browser exits. A zero value causes the cookie to be deleted.

name: cas.authn.mfa.trusted.mongo.pool.per-host
description: Total number of connections allowed per host.

name: cas.authn.attribute-repository.attribute-definition-store.json.location
description:
The location of the resource. Resources can be URLs, or files found either on the classpath or outside somewhere in the file system.

In the event the configured resource is a Groovy script, specially if the script set to reload on changes, you may need to adjust the total number of {@code inotify} instances. On Linux, you may need to add the following line to {@code /etc/sysctl.conf}: {@code fs.inotify.max_user_instances = 256}.

You can check the current value via {@code cat /proc/sys/fs/inotify/max_user_instances}.

name: cas.authn.mfa.simple.bypass.rest.url
description: The endpoint URL to contact and retrieve attributes.

name: cas.authn.mfa.gauth.mongo.host
description: MongoDb database host for authentication. Multiple host addresses may be defined, separated by comma. If more than one host is defined, it is assumed that each host contains the port as well, if any. Otherwise the configuration may fallback onto the port defined.

name: cas.authn.jdbc.encode[].password-encoder.type
description:
Define the password encoder type to use. Type may be specified as blank or {@code NONE} to disable password encoding. It may also refer to a fully-qualified class name that implements the Spring Security's {@code PasswordEncoder} interface if you wish you define your own encoder.

The following types may be used:

  • {@code NONE}: No password encoding (i.e. plain-text) takes place.
  • {@code DEFAULT}: Use the {@code DefaultPasswordEncoder} of CAS. For message-digest algorithms via {@code character-encoding} and {@code encoding-algorithm}.
  • {@code BCRYPT}: Use the {@code BCryptPasswordEncoder} based on the strength provided and an optional secret.
  • {@code SCRYPT}: Use the {@code SCryptPasswordEncoder}.
  • {@code PBKDF2}: Use the {@code Pbkdf2PasswordEncoder} based on the strength provided and an optional secret.
  • {@code STANDARD}: Use the {@code StandardPasswordEncoder} based on the secret provided.
  • {@code SSHA}: Use the {@code LdapShaPasswordEncoder} supports Ldap SHA and SSHA (salted-SHA). The values are base-64 encoded and have the label {SHA} or {SSHA} prepended to the encoded hash.
  • {@code GLIBC_CRYPT}: Use the {@code GlibcCryptPasswordEncoder} based on the {@code encoding-algorithm}, strength provided and an optional secret.
  • {@code org.example.MyEncoder}: An implementation of {@code PasswordEncoder} of your own choosing.
  • {@code file:///path/to/script.groovy}: Path to a Groovy script charged with handling password encoding operations.

name: cas.consent.ldap.idle-time
description: Removes connections from the pool based on how long they have been idle in the available queue. Prunes connections that have been idle for more than the indicated amount.

name: cas.server.tomcat.remote-addr.allowed-client-ip-address-regex
description: A regular expression (using java.util.regex) that the remote client's IP address is compared to. If this attribute is specified, the remote address MUST match for this request to be accepted. If this attribute is not specified, all requests will be accepted UNLESS the remote address matches a deny pattern.

name: cas.monitor.ldap[].trust-store-type
description:
The type of trust keystore that determines which certificates or certificate authorities are trusted.
Types depend on underlying java platform, typically {@code PKCS12} or {@code JKS}.
If left blank, defaults to the default keystore type indicated
by the underlying Java platform.

name: cas.authn.throttle.bucket4j.bandwidth[].refill-strategy
description:
Describes how the bucket should be refilled. Specifies the speed of tokens regeneration. Available values are as follows:
  • {@code GREEDY}: This type of refill regenerates tokens in a greedy manner; it tries to add the tokens to bucket as soon as possible. For example refill "10 tokens per 1 second" adds 1 token per each 100 millisecond; in other words refill will not wait 1 second to regenerate 10 tokens.
  • {@code INTERVALLY}: This type of refill regenerates tokens in intervally manner. "Intervally" in opposite to "greedy" will wait until whole period would be elapsed before regenerating tokens.

name: cas.spring.cloud.aws.dynamo-db.credential-secret-key

name: cas.authn.mfa.web-authn.redis.timeout

Remember that if you have more than one authentication handler of the same type, the names must be defined uniquely for each authentication scheme. Failing to do so may force CAS to not register authentication handlers with a duplicate name.

name: cas.consent.jpa.autocommit

name: cas.ticket.registry.hazelcast.crypto.alg

name: cas.authn.pm.ldap[].trust-manager

Trust Manager options. Trust managers are responsible for managing the trust material that is used when making LDAP trust decisions, and for deciding whether credentials presented by a peer should be accepted. Accepted values are: *
  • {@code DEFAULT}: Enable and force the default JVM trust managers.
  • {@code ANY}: Trust any client or server.

name: cas.service-registry.stream.hazelcast.config.cluster.discovery.gcp.label
description: A filter to look only for instances labeled as specified; property format: {@code key=value}.

name: cas.ticket.registry.redis.queue-identifier
description: Identifier for this CAS server node that tags the sender/receiver in the queue and avoid processing of inbound calls. If left blank, an identifier is generated automatically and kept in memory.

name: cas.service-registry.redis.cluster.adaptive-topology-refresh
description: Whether adaptive topology refreshing using all available refresh triggers should be used.

name: cas.authn.throttle.hazelcast.cluster.network.port-auto-increment
description: You may also want to choose to use only one port. In that case, you can disable the auto-increment feature of port.

name: cas.ticket.registry.cosmos-db.indexing-mode
description:
Specifies the supported indexing modes in the Azure Cosmos DB database service. Accepted values are:
  • {@code CONSISTENT}: Index is updated synchronously with a create or update operation. With consistent indexing, query behavior is the same as the default consistency level for the collection. The index is always kept up to date with the data.
  • {@code LAZY}: Index is updated asynchronously with respect to a create or update operation. With lazy indexing, queries are eventually consistent. The index is updated when the collection is idle.
  • {@code NONE}: No index is provided. Setting IndexingMode to "None" drops the index. Use this if you don't want to maintain the index for a document collection, to save the storage cost or improve the write throughput. Your queries will degenerate to scans of the entire collection.

name: cas.authn.cognito.principal-transformation.case-conversion

Indicate whether the principal identifier should be transformed into upper-case, lower-case, etc. Available values are as follows:
  • {@code NONE}: No conversion.
  • {@code LOWERCASE}: Lowercase conversion.
  • {@code UPPERCASE}: Uppercase conversion.

Validation is performed by the validateObject() method of the factory associated with the pool. If the object fails to validate, it will be removed from the pool and destroyed.

name: cas.authn.surrogate.simple.binary-attributes

name: cas.authn.mfa.gauth.dynamo-db.client-execution-timeout

name: cas.authn.ldap[].subtree-search

name: cas.saml-sp.docu-sign.signature-location

name: cas.authn.jdbc.search[].pool.max-size

Controls the maximum number of connections to keep
in the pool, including both idle and in-use connections.

name: cas.ticket.registry.dynamo-db.crypto.encryption.key
description: The encryption key. The encryption key by default and unless specified otherwise must be randomly-generated string whose length is defined by the encryption key size setting.

name: cas.authn.mfa.web-authn.redis.database
description: Database index used by the connection factory.

name: cas.authn.pm.reset.crypto.strategy-type
description:
Control the cipher sequence of operations. The accepted values are:
  • {@code ENCRYPT_AND_SIGN}: Encrypt the value first, and then sign.
  • {@code SIGN_AND_ENCRYPT}: Sign the value first, and then encrypt.

name: cas.events.redis.cluster.nodes[].port
description: Server's port number.

name: cas.saml-sp.asana.signature-location
