The type of keystore. {@code PKCS12} or {@code JKS}.
If left blank, defaults to the default keystore type indicated
by the underlying Java platform.

name: cas.audit.jdbc.pool.keep-alive-time
description: This property controls the keepalive interval for a connection in the pool. An in-use connection will never be tested by the keepalive thread, only when it is idle will it be tested. Default is zero, which disables this feature.

name: cas.authn.pm.ldap[].pool-passivator
description:
You may receive unexpected LDAP failures, when CAS is configured to authenticate using {@code DIRECT} or {@code AUTHENTICATED} types and LDAP is locked down to not allow anonymous binds/searches. Every second attempt with a given LDAP connection from the pool would fail if it was on the same connection as a failed login attempt, and the regular connection validator would similarly fail. When a connection is returned back to a pool, it still may contain the principal and credentials from the previous attempt. Before the next bind attempt using that connection, the validator tries to validate the connection again but fails because it’s no longer trying with the configured bind credentials but with whatever user DN was used in the previous step. Given the validation failure, the connection is closed and CAS would deny access by default. Passivators attempt to reconnect to LDAP with the configured bind credentials, effectively resetting the connection to what it should be after each bind request. Furthermore if you are seeing errors in the logs that resemble a 'Operation exception encountered, reopening connection' type of message, this usually is an indication that the connection pool’s validation timeout established and created by CAS is greater than the timeout configured in the LDAP server, or more likely, in the load balancer in front of the LDAP servers. You can adjust the LDAP server session’s timeout for connections, or you can teach CAS to use a validity period that is equal or less than the LDAP server session’s timeout. Accepted values are:
  • {@code NONE}: No passivation takes place.
  • {@code BIND}: The default behavior which passivates a connection by performing a bind operation on it. This option requires the availability of bind credentials when establishing connections to LDAP.

name: cas.authn.oauth.access-token.create-as-jwt
description: Create access token as JWTs.

name: cas.events.influx-db.password
description: InfluxDb connection password.

name: cas.authn.mfa.gauth.crypto.strategy-type
description:
Control the cipher sequence of operations. The accepted values are:
  • {@code ENCRYPT_AND_SIGN}: Encrypt the value first, and then sign.
  • {@code SIGN_AND_ENCRYPT}: Sign the value first, and then encrypt.

name: cas.authn.x509.ldap.pool-passivator
description:
You may receive unexpected LDAP failures, when CAS is configured to authenticate using {@code DIRECT} or {@code AUTHENTICATED} types and LDAP is locked down to not allow anonymous binds/searches. Every second attempt with a given LDAP connection from the pool would fail if it was on the same connection as a failed login attempt, and the regular connection validator would similarly fail. When a connection is returned back to a pool, it still may contain the principal and credentials from the previous attempt. Before the next bind attempt using that connection, the validator tries to validate the connection again but fails because it’s no longer trying with the configured bind credentials but with whatever user DN was used in the previous step. Given the validation failure, the connection is closed and CAS would deny access by default. Passivators attempt to reconnect to LDAP with the configured bind credentials, effectively resetting the connection to what it should be after each bind request. Furthermore if you are seeing errors in the logs that resemble a 'Operation exception encountered, reopening connection' type of message, this usually is an indication that the connection pool’s validation timeout established and created by CAS is greater than the timeout configured in the LDAP server, or more likely, in the load balancer in front of the LDAP servers. You can adjust the LDAP server session’s timeout for connections, or you can teach CAS to use a validity period that is equal or less than the LDAP server session’s timeout. Accepted values are:
  • {@code NONE}: No passivation takes place.
  • {@code BIND}: The default behavior which passivates a connection by performing a bind operation on it. This option requires the availability of bind credentials when establishing connections to LDAP.

The subject can either be defined verbaitm, or it may point to a message key in the language bundle using the syntax {@code #{subject-language-key}}. This key should point to a valid message defined in the appropriate language bundle that is then picked up via the active locale. In case where the language code cannot resolve the real subject, a default subject value would be used.

name: cas.monitor.endpoints.ldap.base-dn
description: Base DN to use. There may be scenarios where different parts of a single LDAP tree could be considered as base-dns. Rather than duplicating the LDAP configuration block for each individual base-dn, each entry can be specified and joined together using a special delimiter character. The user DN is retrieved using the combination of all base-dn and DN resolvers in the order defined. DN resolution should fail if multiple DNs are found. Otherwise the first DN found is returned. Usual syntax is: {@code subtreeA,dc=example,dc=net|subtreeC,dc=example,dc=net}.

name: cas.authn.jdbc.bind[].password-encoder.character-encoding

The encoding algorithm to use such as 'UTF-8'.
Relevant when the type used is {@code DEFAULT}.

name: cas.tgc.crypto.alg
description: The signing/encryption algorithm to use.

description: Attribute to use when generating nameids for this SP.

name: cas.service-registry.stream.hazelcast.config.cluster.discovery.jclouds.tag-keys

Whether to discover and query all cluster nodes for obtaining the
cluster topology. When set to false, only the initial seed nodes are
used as sources for topology discovery.

description:
By default initial size of bucket equals to capacity.
But sometimes, you may want to have lesser initial size,
for example for case of cold start in order to prevent denial of service.

description: Custom parameters in form of key-value pairs sent along in authZ requests, etc.

The maximum number of milliseconds that the

name: cas.authn.pm.reset.mail.text
description:
Email message body. Could be plain text or a reference to an external file that would serve as a template.

If specified as a path to an external file with an extension {@code .gtemplate}, then the email message body would be processed using the Groovy template engine. The template engine uses JSP style <% %> script and <%= %> expression syntax or GString style expressions. The variable {@code out} is bound to the writer that the template is being written to.

If using plain text, the contents are processed for string subtitution candidates using named variables. For example, you may refer to an expected url variable in the email text via {@code ${url}}, or use {@code ${token}} to locate the token variable. In certain cases, additional parameters are passed to the email body processor that might include authentication and/or principal attributes, the available locale, client http information, etc.

name: cas.authn.adaptive.risk.response.risky-authentication-attribute
description: If an authentication attempt is deemed risky, communicate the nature of this attempt back to the application via a special attribute in the final CAS response indicated here.

name: cas.authn.pm.ldap[].name
description: Name of the LDAP handler.

name: cas.service-registry.jpa.enabled
description: Whether managing services via JPA is enabled.

name: cas.http-web-request.cors.allow-credentials
description: The Access-Control-Allow-Credentials header Indicates whether or not the response to the request can be exposed when the credentials flag is true.  When used as part of a response to a preflight request, this indicates whether or not the actual request can be made using credentials. Note that simple GET requests are not preflighted, and so if a request is made for a resource with credentials, if this header is not returned with the resource, the response is ignored by the browser and not returned to web content.

name: cas.authn.mfa.u2f.jpa.user

The database user.

The database user must have sufficient permissions to be able to handle schema changes and updates, when needed.

name: cas.authn.mfa.gauth.ldap.validate-timeout

name: cas.authn.mfa.core.provider-selection-enabled
description: In the event that multiple multifactor authentication providers are determined for a multifactor authentication transaction, this setting will allow one to interactively choose a provider out of the list of available providers. A trigger may be designed to support more than one provider, and rather than letting CAS auto-determine the selected provider via scripts or ranking strategies, this method puts the choice back onto the user to decide which provider makes the most sense at any given time.

name: cas.locale.cookie.domain
description: Cookie domain. Specifies the domain within which this cookie should be presented. The form of the domain name is specified by RFC 2965. A domain name begins with a dot (.foo.com) and means that the cookie is visible to servers in a specified Domain Name System (DNS) zone (for example, www.foo.com, but not a.b.foo.com). By default, cookies are only returned to the server that sent them.

name: cas.authn.surrogate.ldap.member-attribute-value-regex

The regular expression pattern is expected to contain at least a single group whose value on a successful match indicates the qualified impersonated user by admin.

name: cas.authn.passwordless.accounts.ldap.hostname-verifier

If the special value of 0 (zero) is used, then Tomcat will select a free port at random to use for this connector. This is typically only useful in embedded and testing applications.

name: cas.authn.mfa.simple.failure-mode
description:
The failure mode policy for this MFA provider. The authentication policy by default supports fail-closed mode, which means that if you attempt to exercise a particular provider available to CAS and the provider cannot be reached, authentication will be stopped and an error will be displayed. You can of course change this behavior so that authentication proceeds without exercising the provider functionality, if that provider cannot respond. Each defined multifactor authentication provider can set its own failure mode policy. Failure modes set at this location will override the global failure mode, but defer to any failure mode set by the registered service. Available values are as follows:
  • {@code OPEN}: Disallow MFA, proceed with authentication but don't communicate MFA to the RP.
  • {@code CLOSED}: Disallow MFA, block with authentication.
  • {@code PHANTOM}: Disallow MFA, proceed with authentication and communicate MFA to the RP.
  • {@code NONE}: Do not check for failure at all.
  • {@code UNDEFINED}: The default one indicating that no failure mode is set at all.

name: cas.authn.passwordless.tokens.jpa.isolate-internal-queries

This property determines whether data source isolates internal pool queries, such as the connection alive test, in their own transaction.

Since these are typically read-only queries, it is rarely necessary to encapsulate them in their own transaction. This property only applies if {@link #autocommit} is disabled.

name: cas.authn.mfa.web-authn.ldap.validator.type
description:
Determine the LDAP validator type.

The following LDAP validators can be used to test connection health status:

  • {@code search}: Validates a connection is healthy by performing a search operation. Validation is considered successful if the search result size is greater than zero.
  • {@code none}: No validation takes place.
  • {@code compare}: Validates a connection is healthy by performing a compare operation.

name: cas.acme.retry-internal

name: cas.authn.mfa.gauth.ldap.sasl-security-strength

name: cas.consent.jpa.physical-naming-strategy-class-name

name: cas.authn.jdbc.query[].password-encoder.type
description:
Define the password encoder type to use. Type may be specified as blank or {@code NONE} to disable password encoding. It may also refer to a fully-qualified class name that implements the Spring Security's {@code PasswordEncoder} interface if you wish you define your own encoder.

The following types may be used:

  • {@code NONE}: No password encoding (i.e. plain-text) takes place.
  • {@code DEFAULT}: Use the {@code DefaultPasswordEncoder} of CAS. For message-digest algorithms via {@code character-encoding} and {@code encoding-algorithm}.
  • {@code BCRYPT}: Use the {@code BCryptPasswordEncoder} based on the strength provided and an optional secret.
  • {@code SCRYPT}: Use the {@code SCryptPasswordEncoder}.
  • {@code PBKDF2}: Use the {@code Pbkdf2PasswordEncoder} based on the strength provided and an optional secret.
  • {@code STANDARD}: Use the {@code StandardPasswordEncoder} based on the secret provided.
  • {@code SSHA}: Use the {@code LdapShaPasswordEncoder} supports Ldap SHA and SSHA (salted-SHA). The values are base-64 encoded and have the label {SHA} or {SSHA} prepended to the encoded hash.
  • {@code GLIBC_CRYPT}: Use the {@code GlibcCryptPasswordEncoder} based on the {@code encoding-algorithm}, strength provided and an optional secret.
  • {@code org.example.MyEncoder}: An implementation of {@code PasswordEncoder} of your own choosing.
  • {@code file:///path/to/script.groovy}: Path to a Groovy script charged with handling password encoding operations.

name: cas.authn.attribute-repository.redis[].share-native-connections
description:
The shared native connection is never closed by Lettuce connection, therefore it is not validated by default when connections are retrieved.
If this setting is {@code true}, a shared connection will be used for regular operations and
a connection provider will be used to select a connection for blocking and tx operations only, which
should not share a connection. If native connection sharing is disabled, new (or pooled) connections will be used for all operations.
By default, multiple connections share a single thread-safe native connection. If you enable connection pooling,
then native connection sharing will be disabled and the connection pool will be used for all operations.
You may however explicitly control connection sharing via this setting as an override.

name: cas.authn.pm.ldap[].trust-store-type

The type of trust keystore that determines which certificates or certificate authorities are trusted.
Types depend on underlying java platform, typically {@code PKCS12} or {@code JKS}.
If left blank, defaults to the default keystore type indicated
by the underlying Java platform.

name: cas.ticket.registry.jpa.ddl-auto
description:
Hibernate feature to automatically validate and exports DDL to the schema. By default, creates and drops the schema automatically when a session is starts and ends. Setting the value to {@code validate} or {@code none} may be more desirable for production, but any of the following options can be used:
  • {@code validate}: Validate the schema, but make no changes to the database.
  • {@code update}: Update the schema.
  • {@code create}: Create the schema, destroying previous data.
  • {@code create-drop}: Drop the schema at the end of the session.
  • {@code none}: Do nothing.

Note that during a version migration where any schema has changed {@code create-drop} will result in the loss of all data as soon as CAS is started. For transient data like tickets this is probably not an issue, but in cases like the audit table important data could be lost. Using `update`, while safe for data, is confirmed to result in invalid database state. {@code validate} or {@code none} settings are likely the only safe options for production use.

For more info, see this.

It is the hazelcast port that the service is configured with, this must be the same for all matched containers in order to work, and just using the default of 5701 is the simplest way to go.

name: cas.authn.qr.allowed-origins
description:
Configure allowed {@code Origin} header values. This check is mostly designed for browser clients. There is nothing preventing other types of client to modify the {@code Origin} header value.

When SockJS is enabled and origins are restricted, transport types that do not allow to check request origin (Iframe based transports) are disabled. As a consequence, IE 6 to 9 are not supported when origins are restricted.

Each provided allowed origin must start by "http://", "https://" or be "*" (means that all origins are allowed). By default, only same origin requests are allowed (empty list).

name: cas.warning-cookie.name
description: Cookie name. Constructs a cookie with a specified name and value. The name must conform to RFC 2965. That means it can contain only ASCII alphanumeric characters and cannot contain commas, semicolons, or white space or begin with a {@code $} character. The cookie's name cannot be changed after creation. By default, cookies are created according to the RFC 2965 cookie specification. Cookie names are automatically calculated assigned by CAS at runtime, and there is usually no need to customize the name or assign it a different value unless a special use case warrants the change.

When used by {@link PasswordEncoderTypes#ARGON2} or {@link PasswordEncoderTypes#PBKDF2}, it indicates the salt strength.

description: Returns whether objects borrowed from the pool will be validated before being returned from the borrowObject() method. Validation is performed by the validateObject() method of the factory associated with the pool. If the object fails to validate, it will be removed from the pool and destroyed, and a new attempt will be made to borrow an object from the pool.

name: cas.authn.throttle.ldap.page-size
description: Request that the server return results in batches of a specific size. See RFC 2696. This control is often used to work around server result size limits. A negative/zero value disables paged requests.

name: cas.authn.saml-idp.metadata.jpa.batch-size
description: A non-zero value enables use of JDBC2 batch updates by Hibernate. e.g. recommended values between 5 and 30.

name: cas.authn.jdbc.search[].pool.suspension
description:
Whether or not pool suspension is allowed.

There is a performance impact when pool suspension is enabled. Unless you need it (for a redundancy system for example) do not enable it.

name: cas.authn.attribute-repository.ldap[].validator.attribute-name
description: Attribute name to use for the compare validator.

name: cas.audit.dynamo-db.profile-name
description: Profile name to use.

name: cas.monitor.endpoints.jdbc.pool.max-wait
description:
Sets the maximum time in seconds that this data source will wait while attempting to connect to a database.

A value of zero specifies that the timeout is the default system timeout if there is one; otherwise, it specifies that there is no timeout.

name: cas.events.jpa.url
description: The database connection URL.

name: cas.saml-sp.symplicity.entity-ids
description: List of entityIds allowed for this service provider. Multiple ids can be specified in the event that the metadata is an aggregate.

name: cas.authn.mfa.gauth.redis.cluster.nodes
description: List of nodes available in the redis cluster.

name: cas.spring.cloud.dynamo-db.proxy-password
description: Optionally specifies the proxy password to connect through.

name: cas.authn.saml-idp.core.session-replication.cookie.secure
description: True if sending this cookie should be restricted to a secure protocol, or false if the it can be sent using any protocol.

name: cas.authn.syncope.principal-transformation.prefix
description: Prefix to add to the principal id prior to authentication.

name: cas.consent.redis.sentinel.node
description: list of host:port pairs.

name: cas.authn.mfa.web-authn.bypass.authentication-attribute-value
description: Optionally, skip multifactor authentication based on designated authentication attribute values.

name: cas.events.dynamo-db.region
description: AWS region used.

name: cas.authn.attribute-repository.jdbc[].single-row
description:
Designed to work against a table where there is a mapping of one row to one user.
The fields in the table structure is assumed to match {@code username|name|lastname|address}
where there is only a single row per user.
Setting this setting to {@code false} will force CAS to work against a table where
there is a mapping of one row to one user.
The fields in the table structure is assumed to match {@code username|attr_name|attr_value}
where there is more than one row per username.

name: cas.ticket.tgt.core.only-track-most-recent-session
description: Flag to control whether to track most recent SSO sessions. As multiple tickets may be issued for the same application, this impacts how session information is tracked for every ticket which then has a subsequent impact on logout.

name: cas.authn.passwordless.accounts.rest.method
description: HTTP method to use when contacting the rest endpoint. Examples include {@code GET, POST}, etc.

name: cas.authn.cassandra.ssl-protocols
description: Set the protocol versions enabled for use on this engine. Once the setting is set, only protocols listed in the protocols parameter are enabled for use.

name: cas.standalone.configuration-security.alg
description: Algorithm to use when deciphering settings. Default algorithm is {@code PBEWithMD5AndTripleDES}.

name: cas.ticket.registry.mongo.port
description: MongoDb database port.

name: cas.sms-provider.twilio.token
description: Twilio secret token used for authentication.

name: cas.authn.pac4j.provisioning.scim.enabled
description: Whether provisioning to SCIM targets should be enabled for delegated authentication attempts.

name: cas.authn.pac4j.oidc[].generic.token-expiration-advance
description: Default time period advance (in seconds) for considering an access token expired.

name: cas.ticket.registry.in-memory.initial-capacity
description: The initial capacity of the underlying memory store. The implementation performs internal sizing to accommodate this many elements.

name: cas.authn.jdbc.query[].principal-transformation.blocking-pattern
description:
A regular expression that will be used against the username
to match for blocking/forbidden values.
If a match is found, an exception will be thrown
and principal transformation will fail.

name: cas.service-registry.git.sign-commits
description: Whether commits should be signed.

name: cas.service-registry.dynamo-db.proxy-username
description: Optionally specifies the proxy username to connect through.

name: cas.authn.attribute-repository.core.expiration-time-unit
description: Expiration caching time unit for attributes.

name: cas.authn.jdbc.search[].principal-transformation.prefix
description: Prefix to add to the principal id prior to authentication.

name: cas.authn.azure-active-directory.order
description: The order of this authentication handler in the chain.

name: cas.authn.x509.mixed-mode
description: Determine whether X509 authentication should allow other forms of authentication such as username/password. If this setting is turned off, typically the ability to view the login form as the primary form of authentication is turned off.

name: cas.ticket.registry.redis.cluster.nodes
description: List of nodes available in the redis cluster.

name: cas.authn.x509.webflow.port
description:
Port that is used to enact x509 client authentication as a separate connector. Configuration of a separate server connector and port allows the separation of client-auth functionality from the rest of the server, allowing for opt-in behavior.

To activate, a non-zero port must be specified.

name: cas.service-registry.stream.hazelcast.config.cluster.discovery.jclouds.tag-values
description: Filters cloud instances with tags (optional) Can be used with comma separated values for multiple values.

name: cas.authn.wsfed[].principal.principal-resolution-conflict-strategy
description:
In the event that the principal resolution engine resolves
more than one principal, (specially if such principals in the chain
have different identifiers), this setting determines strategy by which
the principal id would be chosen from the chain.
Accepted values are: {@code last}, {@code first}.

name: cas.authn.mfa.web-authn.redis.cluster.username
description: The cluster connection's username.

name: cas.saml-sp.safari-online.sign-responses
description: Indicate whether responses should be signed.

name: cas.sms-provider.sns.profile-name
description: Profile name to use.

name: cas.authn.oidc.jwks.revocation.schedule.repeat-interval
description: String representation of a repeat interval of re-loading data for a data store implementation. This is the timeout between consecutive job’s executions.

name: cas.ticket.registry.ignite.crypto.signing.key-size
description: The signing key size.

name: cas.authn.mfa.radius.server.retries
description: Number of re-try attempts when dealing with connection and authentication failures.

name: cas.saml-sp.black-baud.description
description: Description of this service provider as it's stored in the registry.

name: cas.consent.redis.cluster.nodes
description: List of nodes available in the redis cluster.

name: cas.authn.pac4j.saml[].metadata.service-provider.mongo.replica-set
description:
A replica set in MongoDB is a group of {@code mongod} processes that maintain
the same data set. Replica sets provide redundancy and high availability, and are the basis for all production deployments.

name: cas.ticket.registry.hazelcast.cluster.discovery.jclouds.endpoint
description: Defines the endpoint for a generic API such as OpenStack or CloudStack (optional).

name: cas.monitor.ldap[].allow-multiple-entries
description: Set if multiple Entries are allowed.

name: cas.spring.cloud.aws.secrets-manager.client-execution-timeout
description: Client execution timeout.

name: cas.authn.ldap[].password-encoder.iterations
description: When used by {@link PasswordEncoderTypes#PBKDF2}, it indicates the required number of iterations.

name: cas.authn.wsfed[].cookie.domain
description:
Cookie domain. Specifies the domain within which this cookie should be presented.
The form of the domain name is specified by RFC 2965. A domain name begins with a dot (.foo.com)
and means that the cookie is visible to servers in a
specified Domain Name System (DNS) zone (for example, www.foo.com, but not a.b.foo.com).
By default, cookies are only returned to the server that sent them.

name: cas.authn.passwordless.tokens.jpa.driver-class
description: The JDBC driver used to connect to the database.

name: cas.authn.syncope.principal-transformation.pattern
description: A regular expression that will be used against the provided username for username extractions. On a successful match, the first matched group in the pattern will be used as the extracted username.

name: cas.person-directory.principal-transformation.pattern
description: A regular expression that will be used against the provided username for username extractions. On a successful match, the first matched group in the pattern will be used as the extracted username.

name: cas.google-recaptcha.site-key
description: The google reCAPTCHA site key.

name: cas.saml-sp.cher-well.entity-ids
description: List of entityIds allowed for this service provider. Multiple ids can be specified in the event that the metadata is an aggregate.

name: cas.authn.attribute-repository.jdbc[].id
description: A value can be assigned to this field to uniquely identify this resolver.

name: cas.authn.mfa.radius.failover-on-authentication-failure
description: In the event that radius authentication fails, fail over to the next server in the list.

name: cas.authn.wsfed[].cookie.crypto.alg
description: The signing/encryption algorithm to use.

name: cas.authn.accept.password-policy.warn-all
description: Always display the password expiration warning regardless.

name: cas.authn.oauth.crypto.encryption-enabled
description: Whether crypto encryption operations are enabled.

name: cas.service-registry.stream.hazelcast.config.cluster.discovery.aws.secret-key
description: AWS secret key.

name: cas.service-registry.mail.html
description: Indicate whether the message body should be evaluated as HTML text.

name: cas.authn.throttle.hazelcast.cluster.discovery.azure.group-name
description: The Azure resource group name of the cluster. You can find this in the Azure portal or CLI.

name: cas.saml-sp.sans-sth.description
description: Description of this service provider as it's stored in the registry.

name: cas.authn.throttle.hazelcast.cluster.discovery.jclouds.credential-path
description: Used for cloud providers which require an extra JSON or P12 key file. This denotes the path of that file. Only tested with Google Compute Engine. (Required if Google Compute Engine is used.)

name: cas.authn.throttle.ldap.search-entry-handlers[].merge-attribute.attribute-names
description: The Attribute names.

name: cas.service-registry.ldap.validate-on-checkout
description: Whether connections should be validated when loaned out from the pool.

name: cas.ticket.registry.hazelcast.cluster.discovery.jclouds.group
description: Filters instance groups (optional). When used with AWS it maps to security group.

name: cas.acceptable-usage-policy.jdbc.properties
description: Additional settings provided by Hibernate (or the connection provider) in form of key-value pairs.

name: cas.authn.mfa.inwebo.bypass.credential-class-type
description: Skip multifactor authentication depending on form of primary credentials. Value must equal the fully qualified class name of the credential type.

name: cas.authn.pac4j.core.session-replication.cookie.pin-to-session
description: When generating cookie values, determine whether the value should be compounded and signed with the properties of the current session, such as IP address, user-agent, etc.

name: cas.acceptable-usage-policy.rest.url
description: The endpoint URL to contact and retrieve attributes.

name: cas.authn.mongo.password-encoder.character-encoding
description: The encoding algorithm to use such as 'UTF-8'. Relevant when the type used is {@code DEFAULT}.

name: cas.authn.x509.throw-on-fetch-failure
description: When CRL revocation checking is done via distribution points, decide if fetch failures should throw errors.

name: cas.monitor.endpoints.ldap.validator.type
description:
Determine the LDAP validator type.

The following LDAP validators can be used to test connection health status:

  • {@code search}: Validates a connection is healthy by performing a search operation. Validation is considered successful if the search result size is greater than zero.
  • {@code none}: No validation takes place.
  • {@code compare}: Validates a connection is healthy by performing a compare operation.

name: cas.authn.pac4j.dropbox.callback-url
description: Callback URL to use to return the flow back to the CAS server one the identity provider is successfully done. This may be used at the discretion of the client and its type to build service parameters, redirect URIs, etc. If none is specified, the CAS server's login endpoint will be used as the basis of the final callback url.

name: cas.authn.ldap[].validator.dn
description: DN to compare to use for the compare validator.

name: cas.audit.jdbc.schedule.start-delay
description: String representation of a start delay of loading data for a data store implementation. This is the delay between scheduler startup and first job’s execution

name: cas.authn.pm.ldap[].bind-credential
description: The bind credential to use when connecting to LDAP.

name: cas.saml-sp.sserca.name
description: Name of this service provider.

name: cas.authn.mfa.u2f.redis.pool.lifo
description: Returns whether the pool has LIFO (last in, first out) behaviour with respect to idle objects - always returning the most recently used object from the pool, or as a FIFO (first in, first out) queue, where the pool always returns the oldest object in the idle object pool.

name: cas.authn.pm.forgot-username.google-recaptcha.version
description:
Indicate the version of the recaptcha api. Accepted values are: {@code V2, V3}. Available values are as follows:
  • {@code GOOGLE_RECAPTCHA_V2}: V2 version of the recaptcha API.
  • {@code GOOGLE_RECAPTCHA_V3}: V3 version of the recaptcha API.
  • {@code HCAPTCHA}: hCaptcha.

name: cas.ticket.registry.jpa.pool.name
description: Set the name of the connection pool. This is primarily used for the MBean to uniquely identify the pool configuration.

name: cas.authn.throttle.hazelcast.cluster.discovery.aws.host-header
description: Host header. i.e. {@code ec2.amazonaws.com}. The URL that is the entry point for a web service.

name: cas.authn.x509.ldap.prune-period
description: Removes connections from the pool based on how long they have been idle in the available queue. Run the pruning process at the indicated interval.

name: cas.ticket.registry.hazelcast.cluster.wan-replication.targets[].response-timeout-milliseconds
description: Time, in milliseconds, to be waited for the acknowledgment of a sent WAN event to target cluster.

name: cas.monitor.jdbc.dialect
description: The database dialect is a configuration setting for platform independent software (JPA, Hibernate, etc) which allows such software to translate its generic SQL statements into vendor specific DDL, DML.

name: cas.authn.pac4j.facebook.auto-redirect-type
description:
Auto-redirect to this client. Available values are as follows:
  • {@code SERVER}: Redirect on the server side, typically making CAS invisible.
  • {@code CLIENT}: Redirect on the client side using browser redirects, etc.
  • {@code NONE}: Do nothing and let the selection take place manually.

name: cas.monitor.ldap[].sasl-realm
description: The SASL realm.

name: cas.view.custom-login-form-fields.[key].message-bundle-key
description:
The key for this field found in the message bundle
used to present a label/text in CAS views.

name: cas.consent.dynamo-db.credential-secret-key
description: Use secret key provided by AWS to authenticate.

name: cas.authn.pac4j.oidc[].keycloak.custom-params
description: Custom parameters to send along in authZ requests, etc.

name: cas.authn.mfa.yubikey.redis.pool.test-on-return
description: Returns whether objects borrowed from the pool will be validated when they are returned to the pool via the returnObject() method. Validation is performed by the validateObject() method of the factory associated with the pool. Returning objects that fail validation are destroyed rather then being returned the pool.

name: cas.service-registry.redis.cluster.nodes[].host
description: Server's host address.

name: cas.authn.mfa.web-authn.redis.enabled
description: Whether the module is enabled or not, defaults to true.

name: cas.authn.oidc.discovery.user-info-signing-alg-values-supported
description: Supported algorithms for user-info signing.

name: cas.authn.mfa.u2f.core.bypass.rest.basic-auth-username
description: If REST endpoint is protected via basic authentication, specify the username for authentication.

name: cas.audit.redis.pool.test-on-create
description: Returns whether objects created for the pool will be validated before being returned from the borrowObject() method. Validation is performed by the validateObject() method of the factory associated with the pool. If the object fails to validate, then borrowObject() will fail.

name: cas.authn.ldap[].dn-format
description:
Specify the dn format accepted by the AD authenticator, etc.
Example format might be {@code uid=%s,ou=people,dc=example,dc=org}.

name: cas.authn.mfa.gauth.core.scratch-codes.encryption.key
description: The encryption key. The encryption key by default and unless specified otherwise must be randomly-generated string whose length is defined by the encryption key size setting.

name: cas.authn.groovy.state
description:
Define the scope and state of this authentication handler and the lifecycle in which it can be invoked or activated. Available values are as follows:
  • {@code ACTIVE}: Active authentication handler, and is invoked by default automatically to verify credentials globally.
  • {@code STANDBY}: Authentication handler is in a semi-enabled state, waiting to be called only on-demand when explicitly asked for.

name: cas.authn.x509.principal.principal-transformation.blocking-pattern
description: A regular expression that will be used against the username to match for blocking/forbidden values. If a match is found, an exception will be thrown and principal transformation will fail.

name: cas.authn.adaptive.policy.reject-browsers
description: Comma-separated list of strings representing browser user agents to be rejected from participating in authentication transactions.

name: cas.authn.cloud-directory.facet-name
description: Facet name.

name: cas.authn.surrogate.ldap.connect-timeout
description: Sets the maximum amount of time that connects will block.

name: cas.authn.json.password-encoder.hash-length
description: When used by {@link PasswordEncoderTypes#ARGON2}, it indicates the hash strength/length.

name: cas.interrupt.cookie.secure
description: True if sending this cookie should be restricted to a secure protocol, or false if the it can be sent using any protocol.

name: cas.amazon-sts.connection-timeout
description: Connection timeout.

name: cas.authn.saml-idp.metadata.mongo.pool.life-time
description: The maximum time a pooled connection can live for.  A zero value indicates no limit to the life time.  A pooled connection that has exceeded its life time will be closed and replaced when necessary by a new connection.

name: cas.saml-sp.poll-everywhere.signature-location
description: Signature location used to verify metadata.

name: cas.authn.attribute-repository.rest[].method
description:
HTTP method to use when contacting the rest endpoint.
Examples include {@code GET, POST}, etc.

name: cas.authn.pm.jdbc.physical-naming-strategy-class-name
description: Fully-qualified name of the class that can control the physical naming strategy of hibernate.

name: cas.monitor.endpoints.ldap.deref-aliases
description:
Define how aliases are de-referenced. Accepted values are:
  • {@code NEVER}
  • {@code SEARCHING}: dereference when searching the entries beneath the starting point but not when searching for the starting entry.
  • {@code FINDING}: dereference when searching for the starting entry but not when searching the entries beneath the starting point.
  • {@code ALWAYS}: dereference when searching for the starting entry and when searching the entries beneath the starting point.

name: cas.authn.jdbc.bind[].pool.min-size
description:
Controls the minimum size that the pool is allowed
to reach, including both idle and in-use connections.

name: cas.consent.redis.cluster.nodes[].replica-of
description: Set the id of the master node.

name: cas.service-registry.ldap.search-entry-handlers[].recursive.merge-attributes
description: The Merge attributes.

name: cas.saml-sp.cccco.metadata
description: The location of the metadata for this service provider. Can be a URL or another form of resource.

name: cas.ticket.registry.hazelcast.cluster.discovery.aws.port
description: Hazelcast port. Typically may be set to {@code 5701}. You can set searching for other ports rather than 5701 if you've members on different ports.

name: cas.authn.soap.password-encoder.secret
description: Secret to use with {@link PasswordEncoderTypes#STANDARD}, {@link PasswordEncoderTypes#PBKDF2}, {@link PasswordEncoderTypes#BCRYPT}, {@link PasswordEncoderTypes#GLIBC_CRYPT} password encoders. Secret usually is an optional setting.

name: cas.authn.wsfed[].attributes-type
description:
Indicates how attributes should be recorded into the principal object.
Useful if you wish to additionally resolve attributes on top of what wsfed provides.
Accepted values are {@code CAS,WSFED,BOTH}.

name: cas.authn.throttle.hazelcast.cluster.discovery.jclouds.role-name
description: Used for IAM role support specific to AWS (optional, but if defined, no identity or credential should be defined in the configuration).

name: cas.ticket.registry.mongo.pool.idle-time
description: The maximum idle time of a pooled connection.  A zero value indicates no limit to the idle time.  A pooled connection that has exceeded its idle time will be closed and replaced when necessary by a new connection.

name: cas.saml-sp.benefit-focus.signature-location
description: Signature location used to verify metadata.

name: cas.acceptable-usage-policy.jdbc.pool.suspension
description:
Whether or not pool suspension is allowed.

There is a performance impact when pool suspension is enabled. Unless you need it (for a redundancy system for example) do not enable it.

name: cas.authn.json.state
description:
Define the scope and state of this authentication handler and the lifecycle in which it can be invoked or activated. Available values are as follows:
  • {@code ACTIVE}: Active authentication handler, and is invoked by default automatically to verify credentials globally.
  • {@code STANDBY}: Authentication handler is in a semi-enabled state, waiting to be called only on-demand when explicitly asked for.

name: cas.service-registry.ldap.sasl-authorization-id
description: SASL authorization id.

name: cas.authn.spnego.ldap.search-entry-handlers[].search-referral.limit
description: The default referral limit.

name: cas.authn.mfa.gauth.ldap.validator.attribute-name
description: Attribute name to use for the compare validator.

name: cas.authn.mfa.simple.bypass.rest.headers
description: Headers, defined as a Map, to include in the request when making the REST call. Will overwrite any header that CAS is pre-defined to send and include in the request. Key in the map should be the header name and the value in the map should be the header value.

name: cas.ticket.registry.dynamo-db.write-capacity
description: Write capacity.

name: cas.authn.remote-address.name
description: The name of the authentication handler.

name: cas.authn.jdbc.bind[].dialect
description:
The database dialect is a configuration setting for platform independent software (JPA, Hibernate, etc)
which allows such software to translate its generic SQL statements into vendor specific DDL, DML.

name: cas.authn.mfa.yubikey.mongo.password
description: MongoDb database password for authentication.

name: cas.webflow.session.server.hazelcast.cluster.network.ssl.keystore-password
description: Password to access the key from your keystore file. Only needed when the mutual authentication is used.

name: cas.monitor.endpoints.ldap.validate-on-checkout
description: Whether connections should be validated when loaned out from the pool.

name: cas.authn.pac4j.provisioning.rest.headers
description: Headers, defined as a Map, to include in the request when making the REST call. Will overwrite any header that CAS is pre-defined to send and include in the request. Key in the map should be the header name and the value in the map should be the header value.

name: cas.authn.attribute-repository.azure-active-directory[].api-base-url
description: Base API url used to contact microsoft graph for calls.

name: cas.authn.pac4j.github.principal-id-attribute
description: The attribute found in the identity provider response that may be used to establish the authenticated user and build a profile for CAS.

name: cas.authn.pac4j.oidc[].apple.preferred-jws-algorithm
description:
The JWS algorithm to use forcefully when validating ID tokens.
If none is defined, the first algorithm from metadata will be used.

name: cas.authn.mfa.trusted.dynamo-db.read-capacity
description: Read capacity.

name: cas.authn.saml-idp.metadata.amazon-s3.proxy-username
description: Optionally specifies the proxy username to connect through.

name: cas.authn.attribute-repository.ldap[].attributes
description:
Map of attributes to fetch from the source. Attributes are defined using a key-value structure where CAS allows the attribute name/key to be renamed virtually to a different attribute. The key is the attribute fetched from the data source and the value is the attribute name CAS should use for virtual renames.

Attributes may be allowed to be virtually renamed and remapped. The key in the attribute map is the original attribute, and the value should be the virtually-renamed attribute.

To fetch and resolve attributes that carry tags/options, consider tagging the mapped attribute as such: {@code affiliation=affiliation}.

name: cas.authn.trusted.person-directory.principal-transformation.case-conversion
description:
Indicate whether the principal identifier should be transformed into upper-case, lower-case, etc. Available values are as follows:
  • {@code NONE}: No conversion.
  • {@code LOWERCASE}: Lowercase conversion.
  • {@code UPPERCASE}: Uppercase conversion.

name: cas.saml-sp.sa-manage.name-id-format
description: The forced nameId format to use when generating a response.

name: cas.authn.pac4j.oidc[].azure.client-name
description:
Name of the client mostly for UI purposes and uniqueness.
This name, with 'non-word' characters converted to '-' (e.g. "This Org (New)" becomes "This-Org--New-")
is added to the "class" attribute of the redirect link on the login page, to allow for
custom styling of individual IdPs (e.g. for an organization logo).

name: cas.authn.pac4j.github.auto-redirect-type
description:
Auto-redirect to this client. Available values are as follows:
  • {@code SERVER}: Redirect on the server side, typically making CAS invisible.
  • {@code CLIENT}: Redirect on the client side using browser redirects, etc.
  • {@code NONE}: Do nothing and let the selection take place manually.

name: cas.authn.mfa.radius.name
description: The name of the authentication handler used to verify credentials in MFA. Remember that if you have more than one authentication handler of the same type, the names must be defined uniquely for each authentication scheme. Failing to do so may force CAS to not register authentication handlers with a duplicate name.

name: cas.authn.pm.core.password-policy-password-length
description: The password length used by CAS when suggesting generated passwords.

name: cas.authn.mfa.u2f.name
description: The name of the authentication handler used to verify credentials in MFA. Remember that if you have more than one authentication handler of the same type, the names must be defined uniquely for each authentication scheme. Failing to do so may force CAS to not register authentication handlers with a duplicate name.

name: cas.authn.pac4j.saml[].accepted-skew
description:
Maximum skew in seconds between SP and IDP clocks.
This skew is added onto the {@code NotOnOrAfter} field in seconds
for the SAML response validation.

name: cas.account-registration.provisioning.syncope.headers
description: Headers, defined as a Map, to include in the request when making the REST call. Will overwrite any header that CAS is pre-defined to send and include in the request. Key in the map should be the header name and the value in the map should be the header value.

name: cas.ticket.tgt.remember-me.supported-user-agents
description: Regular expression that, when defined, forces CAS to create a remember-me authentication session if the current user-agent matches this pattern. If a match is not found, remember-me is ignored. If left undefined, remember-me authentication will proceed with the default CAS behavior.

name: cas.authn.radius.password-encoder.character-encoding
description: The encoding algorithm to use such as 'UTF-8'. Relevant when the type used is {@code DEFAULT}.

name: cas.consent.core.webflow.order
description: The order in which the webflow is configured.

name: cas.authn.mfa.trusted.redis.share-native-connections
description: The shared native connection is never closed by Lettuce connection, therefore it is not validated by default when connections are retrieved. If this setting is {@code true}, a shared connection will be used for regular operations and a connection provider will be used to select a connection for blocking and tx operations only, which should not share a connection. If native connection sharing is disabled, new (or pooled) connections will be used for all operations. By default, multiple connections share a single thread-safe native connection. If you enable connection pooling, then native connection sharing will be disabled and the connection pool will be used for all operations. You may however explicitly control connection sharing via this setting as an override.

name: cas.authn.soap.password-encoder.type
description:
Define the password encoder type to use. Type may be specified as blank or {@code NONE} to disable password encoding. It may also refer to a fully-qualified class name that implements the Spring Security's {@code PasswordEncoder} interface if you wish you define your own encoder.

The following types may be used:

  • {@code NONE}: No password encoding (i.e. plain-text) takes place.
  • {@code DEFAULT}: Use the {@code DefaultPasswordEncoder} of CAS. For message-digest algorithms via {@code character-encoding} and {@code encoding-algorithm}.
  • {@code BCRYPT}: Use the {@code BCryptPasswordEncoder} based on the strength provided and an optional secret.
  • {@code SCRYPT}: Use the {@code SCryptPasswordEncoder}.
  • {@code PBKDF2}: Use the {@code Pbkdf2PasswordEncoder} based on the strength provided and an optional secret.
  • {@code STANDARD}: Use the {@code StandardPasswordEncoder} based on the secret provided.
  • {@code SSHA}: Use the {@code LdapShaPasswordEncoder} supports Ldap SHA and SSHA (salted-SHA). The values are base-64 encoded and have the label {SHA} or {SSHA} prepended to the encoded hash.
  • {@code GLIBC_CRYPT}: Use the {@code GlibcCryptPasswordEncoder} based on the {@code encoding-algorithm}, strength provided and an optional secret.
  • {@code org.example.MyEncoder}: An implementation of {@code PasswordEncoder} of your own choosing.
  • {@code file:///path/to/script.groovy}: Path to a Groovy script charged with handling password encoding operations.

Rather than duplicating the LDAP configuration block for each individual base-dn, each entry can be specified and joined together using a special delimiter character. The user DN is retrieved using the combination of all base-dn and DN resolvers in the order defined. DN resolution should fail if multiple DNs are found. Otherwise the first DN found is returned. Usual syntax is: {@code subtreeA,dc=example,dc=net|subtreeC,dc=example,dc=net}.

name: cas.ticket.registry.hazelcast.cluster.core.replicated
description:
A Replicated Map is a distributed key-value data structure where the data is replicated to all members in the cluster. It provides full replication of entries to all members for high speed access. A Replicated Map does not partition data (it does not spread data to different cluster members); instead, it replicates the data to all members. Replication leads to higher memory consumption. However, a Replicated Map has faster read and write access since the data is available on all members. Writes could take place on local/remote members in order to provide write-order, eventually being replicated to all other members.

If you have a large cluster or very high occurrences of updates, the Replicated Map may not scale linearly as expected since it has to replicate update operations to all members in the cluster. Since the replication of updates is performed in an asynchronous manner, Hazelcast recommends you enable back pressure in case your system has high occurrences of updates.

Note that Replicated Map does not guarantee eventual consistency because there are some edge cases that fail to provide consistency.

Replicated Map uses the internal partition system of Hazelcast in order to serialize updates happening on the same key at the same time. This happens by sending updates of the same key to the same Hazelcast member in the cluster.

Due to the asynchronous nature of replication, a Hazelcast member could die before successfully replicating a "write" operation to other members after sending the "write completed" response to its caller during the write process. In this scenario, Hazelcast’s internal partition system promotes one of the replicas of the partition as the primary one. The new primary partition does not have the latest "write" since the dead member could not successfully replicate the update.

name: cas.consent.ldap.block-wait-time
description: The length of time the pool will block. By default the pool will block indefinitely and there is no guarantee that waiting threads will be serviced in the order in which they made their request. This option should be used with a blocking connection pool when you need to control the exact number of connections that can be created

name: cas.authn.attribute-repository.jdbc[].ddl-auto
description:
Hibernate feature to automatically validate and exports DDL to the schema. By default, creates and drops the schema automatically when a session is starts and ends. Setting the value to {@code validate} or {@code none} may be more desirable for production, but any of the following options can be used:
  • {@code validate}: Validate the schema, but make no changes to the database.
  • {@code update}: Update the schema.
  • {@code create}: Create the schema, destroying previous data.
  • {@code create-drop}: Drop the schema at the end of the session.
  • {@code none}: Do nothing.

Note that during a version migration where any schema has changed {@code create-drop} will result in the loss of all data as soon as CAS is started. For transient data like tickets this is probably not an issue, but in cases like the audit table important data could be lost. Using `update`, while safe for data, is confirmed to result in invalid database state. {@code validate} or {@code none} settings are likely the only safe options for production use.

For more info, see this.

name: cas.authn.mfa.simple.token.rank
description:
At times, CAS needs to determine the correct provider when step-up authentication is required. Consider for a moment that CAS already has established an SSO session with/without a provider and has reached a level of authentication. Another incoming request attempts to exercise that SSO session with a different and often competing authentication requirement that may differ from the authentication level CAS has already established. Concretely, examples may be:
  • CAS has achieved an SSO session, but a separate request now requires step-up authentication with DuoSecurity.
  • CAS has achieved an SSO session with an authentication level satisfied by DuoSecurity, but a separate request now requires step-up authentication with YubiKey.
In certain scenarios, CAS will attempt to rank authentication levels and compare them with each other. If CAS already has achieved a level that is higher than what the incoming request requires, no step-up authentication will be performed. If the opposite is true, CAS will route the authentication flow to the required authentication level and upon success, will adjust the SSO session with the new higher authentication level now satisfied. Ranking of authentication methods is done per provider via specific properties for each. Note that the higher the rank value is, the higher on the security scale it remains. A provider that ranks higher with a larger weight value trumps and override others with a lower value.

name: cas.events.jpa.fail-fast-timeout
description:
Set the pool initialization failure timeout.
  • Any value greater than zero will be treated as a timeout for pool initialization. The calling thread will be blocked from continuing until a successful connection to the database, or until the timeout is reached. If the timeout is reached, then a {@code PoolInitializationException} will be thrown.
  • A value of zero will not prevent the pool from starting in the case that a connection cannot be obtained. However, upon start the pool will attempt to obtain a connection and validate that the {@code connectionTestQuery} and {@code connectionInitSql} are valid. If those validations fail, an exception will be thrown. If a connection cannot be obtained, the validation is skipped and the the pool will start and continue to try to obtain connections in the background. This can mean that callers to {@code DataSource#getConnection()} may encounter exceptions.
  • A value less than zero will not bypass any connection attempt and validation during startup, and therefore the pool will start immediately. The pool will continue to try to obtain connections in the background. This can mean that callers to {@code DataSource#getConnection()} may encounter exceptions.
Note that if this timeout value is greater than or equal to zero (0), and therefore an initial connection validation is performed, this timeout does not override the {@code connectionTimeout} or {@code validationTimeout}; they will be honored before this timeout is applied. The default value is one millisecond.

name: cas.authn.ldap[].type
description:
The authentication type.
  • {@code AD} - Users authenticate with {@code sAMAccountName}.
  • {@code AUTHENTICATED} - Manager bind/search type of authentication. If {@code} principalAttributePassword} is empty then a user simple bind is done to validate credentials. Otherwise the given attribute is compared with the given {@code principalAttributePassword} using the {@code SHA} encrypted value of it.
  • {@code ANONYMOUS}: Similar semantics as {@code AUTHENTICATED} except no {@code bindDn} and {@code bindCredential} may be specified to initialize the connection. If {@code principalAttributePassword} is empty then a user simple bind is done to validate credentials. Otherwise the given attribute is compared with the given {@code principalAttributePassword} using the {@code SHA} encrypted value of it.
  • DIRECT: Direct Bind - Compute user DN from format string and perform simple bind. This is relevant when no search is required to compute the DN needed for a bind operation. Use cases for this type are: 1) All users are under a single branch in the directory, {@code e.g. ou=Users,dc=example,dc=org.} 2) The username provided on the CAS login form is part of the DN, e.g. {@code uid=%s,ou=Users,dc=example,dc=org}.
Available values are as follows:
  • {@code AD}: Active Directory.
  • {@code AUTHENTICATED}: Authenticated Search.
  • {@code DIRECT}: Direct Bind.
  • {@code ANONYMOUS}: Anonymous Search.

name: cas.authn.oauth.session-replication.cookie.same-site-policy
description:
If a cookie is only intended to be accessed in a first party context, the developer has the option to apply one of settings {@code SameSite=Lax} or {@code SameSite=Strict} or {@code SameSite=None} to prevent external access.

To safeguard more websites and their users, the new secure-by-default model assumes all cookies should be protected from external access unless otherwise specified. Developers must use a new cookie setting, {@code SameSite=None}, to designate cookies for cross-site access. When the {@code SameSite=None} attribute is present, an additional {@code Secure} attribute is used so cross-site cookies can only be accessed over HTTPS connections.

Accepted values are:
  • {@code Lax}
  • {@code Strict}
  • {@code None}
  • {@code Off}: Disable the generation of the SameSite cookie attribute altogether.
  • Path to a Groovy script that is able to generate the SameSite cookie attribute dynamically.
  • Fully qualified name of a class that implements {@code org.apereo.cas.web.cookie.CookieSameSitePolicy}

name: cas.authn.errors.groovy.location
description:
The location of the resource. Resources can be URLs, or files found either on the classpath or outside somewhere in the file system.

In the event the configured resource is a Groovy script, specially if the script set to reload on changes, you may need to adjust the total number of {@code inotify} instances. On Linux, you may need to add the following line to {@code /etc/sysctl.conf}: {@code fs.inotify.max_user_instances = 256}.

You can check the current value via {@code cat /proc/sys/fs/inotify/max_user_instances}.

name: cas.authn.passwordless.accounts.ldap.pool-passivator
description:
You may receive unexpected LDAP failures, when CAS is configured to authenticate using {@code DIRECT} or {@code AUTHENTICATED} types and LDAP is locked down to not allow anonymous binds/searches. Every second attempt with a given LDAP connection from the pool would fail if it was on the same connection as a failed login attempt, and the regular connection validator would similarly fail. When a connection is returned back to a pool, it still may contain the principal and credentials from the previous attempt. Before the next bind attempt using that connection, the validator tries to validate the connection again but fails because it’s no longer trying with the configured bind credentials but with whatever user DN was used in the previous step. Given the validation failure, the connection is closed and CAS would deny access by default. Passivators attempt to reconnect to LDAP with the configured bind credentials, effectively resetting the connection to what it should be after each bind request. Furthermore if you are seeing errors in the logs that resemble a 'Operation exception encountered, reopening connection' type of message, this usually is an indication that the connection pool’s validation timeout established and created by CAS is greater than the timeout configured in the LDAP server, or more likely, in the load balancer in front of the LDAP servers. You can adjust the LDAP server session’s timeout for connections, or you can teach CAS to use a validity period that is equal or less than the LDAP server session’s timeout. Accepted values are:
  • {@code NONE}: No passivation takes place.
  • {@code BIND}: The default behavior which passivates a connection by performing a bind operation on it. This option requires the availability of bind credentials when establishing connections to LDAP.

name: cas.authn.pac4j.oidc[].apple.use-nonce

name: cas.webflow.session.server.hazelcast.cluster.discovery.azure.subscription-id

name: cas.ticket.registry.hazelcast.cluster.core.max-size-policy
description:
• {@code FREE_HEAP_PERCENTAGE}: Policy based on minimum free JVM heap memory percentage per JVM.
  • {@code FREE_HEAP_SIZE}: Policy based on minimum free JVM heap memory in megabytes per JVM.
  • {@code FREE_NATIVE_MEMORY_PERCENTAGE}: Policy based on minimum free native memory percentage per Hazelcast instance.
  • {@code FREE_NATIVE_MEMORY_SIZE}: Policy based on minimum free native memory in megabytes per Hazelcast instance.
  • {@code PER_NODE}: Policy based on maximum number of entries stored per data structure (map, cache etc) on each Hazelcast instance.
  • {@code PER_PARTITION}: Policy based on maximum number of entries stored per data structure (map, cache etc) on each partition.
  • {@code USED_HEAP_PERCENTAGE}: Policy based on maximum used JVM heap memory percentage per data structure (map, cache etc) on each Hazelcast instance .
  • {@code USED_HEAP_SIZE}: Policy based on maximum used JVM heap memory in megabytes per data structure (map, cache etc) on each Hazelcast instance.
  • {@code USED_NATIVE_MEMORY_PERCENTAGE}: Policy based on maximum used native memory percentage per data structure (map, cache etc) on each Hazelcast instance.
  • {@code USED_NATIVE_MEMORY_SIZE}: Policy based on maximum used native memory in megabytes per data structure (map, cache etc) on each Hazelcast instance .

name: cas.authn.okta.proxy-port
